Every day she works at her business for 14 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal, firewood and fish for her business. She is hoping that through this loan her profit will increase and she will be able to expand her business and save money for future use.

Mtumwa is 47 years old, married, and has six children aged between 8 and 14. She also cares for three additional dependents.

Mtumwa will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Asha, Rukia and Salma. Each woman has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal, firewood,and fish for her business.

loans.name: Hatuchokani Group

texts.en:
Safia has been a food (bites and chips) seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 10 months. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $35. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more breads for her business. She is hoping that through this loan her profit will increase and she will be able to expand her business, save money and pay school fees for her children. Safia is 27 years old, married and has five children ages 10, 9, 3 and 2 years, and the youngest 6 months.

Safia will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Asha and Halima. Each woman has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more bread for her food business.

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en:
Rosalia M., 49, mother of 5 children, owns a store which is connected to her house. People come to her store to buy their needs. Now, she doesn’t have a husband. She runs her business and raises her children alone. She was a saleslady before in a one of the biggest department stores in Bohol. She was not happy with her previous job. She stopped working and established her own business.

She is asking for a CEVI loan of Php 5,000. She will use the loan to buy more products to sell in her store. She also has a plan of having a bakery. With the help of her daughter who works at ICM, a popular mall in Tagbilaran, she might be able to realize her dreams. She is interested in looking into some other opportunities that could augment their limited income.

CEVI helps Rosalia achieve her dreams. She is provided with credit assistance, training, and the insurance coverage CEVI gives to all its clients.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her store

loans.name: Lurline

texts.en:
Lurline M., 36, is a tombstone maker and carver. She carves and makes tombstones in memory of the dead. She started her business in 2004 with the capital of Php 15,000. Her business is situated at Loon Public Market. People come to order specific tombstones for their deceased relatives. She is happy in her business because this gives her income to feed her family well. She has only one child named Jun Marlo M., 7 years old. She worked previously as an Avon/Natasha fashion dealer, until she joined CEVI credit program.

She is requesting a loan of Php 8,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy marble and granite. In this way, she will be able to accommodate the orders she receives from her important clients.

CEVI gives Lurline easy access to credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage just by joining the program.

loans.use: To buy marble and granite for her tombstone business

loans.name: Den

texts.en: Mrs. Den L. is a villager in Sou Sean village in Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. In this plantation, she can earn a little income to support her household. In order to improve her family's living conditions, she decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy a piece of land for cultivating rice. Her husband, Mr. Yos Chan Chhean, is a security guard who has a low salary. Mrs. Den L. is 50 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the other is attending the local school. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To add to her savings to buy a piece of land for cultivating rice.

loans.name: Maria Linda

texts.en:
Maria Linda J., 38, owns a small restaurant and store. She has three children, namely Reina Marie, Analou, and Quennie Marie J.. She started her business in 1999 with the capital of Php 5,000. Until now, she has her business growing and established. Her business is situated near their house and the profits she gets from selling food are what she uses to pay the tuition fees of her children.

She is asking for a loan of Php 3,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional ingredients for her small restaurant. She believes that her loan will bring her more profit to sustain her family better.

CEVI supports Linda in growing her food business. Through credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage, more CEVI clients are able to grow their businesses.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her store

loans.name: Jennifer's Group

texts.en:
Jennifer T. is the treasurer of Kamwokya II development group in Kamwokya. She is a married lady and the mother of 4 children of whom two are still in school, a girl in her final year at Makerere University, while the boy is just beginning high school.

Jennifer has two businesses. She is a poultry farmer with layers. She recently sold off all her layers and has booked 500 more layers as well as a few broilers that she hopes will be ready during the Easter season. She also has a cosmetics shop where she sells ladies’ beauty products like Vaseline, lotions, weaves and braids. She is grateful that she is able to sell from her home; hence doesn't have to rent. Jennifer needs another loan to complete payment for her birds as well as stocking feed for those birds.

loans.use: paying the balance for her layer-chicks plus buying chicken feed in large quantity

loans.name: Ath

texts.en: Mr. Ath D. is a villager in Tom Por village in Kampong Cham province. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. In this plantation he needs fertilizer to make his crop more productive. In order to deal with this problem, he decided to ask for a loan for this purpose and he would use the rest of the loan to purchase chickens and ducks for breeding. His wife, Mrs. Van Srey Chheang, is an animal breeder. Mr. Ath D. is 36 years old and the father of a child who is too young to work or study. His wife is presented with him in the picture.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to support the field and make his crop more productive.

loans.name: Amanullah

texts.en: Amanullah is the son of D. K.. He lives in district 9 of Kabul, Afghanistan and he supports all his family members through his monthly income. He is a carpet weaver and would like to expand his business. He has requested an individual loan of 30,000 Afghani for a term of 12 months. He is confident that through the loan he can buy good quality weaving materials and can weave carpets for which the demand in the bazaar is high.

loans.use: Buying good quality raw materials for weaving carpets

loans.name: Maisha Bora Group

texts.en:
Khadija is a tailor and painter in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar. She has done this work for four years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $40, working every day for 14 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more tailoring and painting materials for her business. She is hoping that through this loan her profit will increase and she will be able to expand her business and save money for future use. Khadija is 26 years old and married.

Khadija will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Asaa, Sada H., Chiku, Sichana and Sada S.. Each woman has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring and painting materials for the expansion of her business.

loans.name: Ser

texts.en: Mrs. Ser S. lives in Tom Por village in Kampong Cham province. She sells mangoes. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more mangoes to resell. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Touy Chen, is a palm juice collector and is a construction worker. Mrs. Ser S. is 44 years old and the mother of four children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while another is enrolled in the local school and the remaining is too young to work or study. Her husband is presented with her in the picture.

loans.use: To buy mangoes to re-sell.

loans.name: Soeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Soeurn S. is a villager in Pong Toek village in Kampong Cham province. She owns a small general store where she sells grocery goods. She is a 54 year-old widow with a child attending the local school. Although Mrs. Soeurn S. tries to work hard, she still lives in poor conditions. In order to improve these conditions, Mrs. Soeurn S. is requesting a loan to buy a cow for breeding to increase her income to support her family living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Wapendanao Group

texts.en:
Fatma is a clothes and chicken seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar, work she had done for five years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $125 and every day she works at her business from 8am to 10pm. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes and chicken for her business. She is hoping that through this loan her profit will increase and she will be able to expand her business. Fatma is 45 years old, married, and has five children ages 20, 18, 12, 10 and 8.

Fatma will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Mwanahamis, Maryam, Khadija and Asha. Each woman has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and chicken for her business.

loans.name: Ken

texts.en:
Mrs. Ken P. is a villager in Angk village in Kampong Cham province. She is a duck breeder. Her husband, Mr. Seim Seng, is a farmer who owns a piece of land and cultivates rice for a living. In his plantation, he does not earn enough income to support his family. In order to improve their standard of living, Mrs. Ken P. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy a plot of land to cultivate rice.

Mrs. Ken P. is 39 years old and the mother of two children who are attending the local school. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Husna

texts.en:
Husna has been selling clothes and charcoal in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for three years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $25. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes and charcoal for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to expand her business.

Husna is 23 years old, married, and has two children aged 1 and 4.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and charcoal to expand her business.

loans.name: Sokkhai

texts.en: Mrs. Sokkhai C. is a villager in Ba Chay village in Kampong Cham province. She and her husband, Mr. Sam Oun, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice. In their plantation, they face some problems because their field is infertile and has a lot of insects. In order to deal with these problems, Mrs. Sokkhai C. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides, and use the rest of the money to buy pump supplies for water to support the field. She is 42 years old and the mother of five children, three of whom are workers in different positions while the others are too young to work or study. Her husband is shown on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides, and to buy pump supplies for water to support the field.

loans.name: Vorn

texts.en: Mr. Vorn S. is a villager in Pong Toek village in Kampong Cham province. He uses rice to make wine. Aside from this career, he is a pig breeder. Since his breeding pigs business is doing well, he wants to expand it by purchasing ten more piglets and expand their piggery. He hopes to increase his earnings and improve his family’s quality of life. His wife, Mrs. Tan Seng Hin, is a Khmer cake seller who can make a little income to support the family. Mr. Vorn S. is a 56-year-old father of a child who is attending the local school. His wife is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy piglets and build a piggery for those pigs.

loans.name: Ediltrudes

texts.en:
Ediltrudes E. sells coco shells for "calamay" (sticky rice), a type of delicacy that Bohol is known for because of its sticky sugary taste. Because more and more people make "calamay" as a business, all the more people need coco shells to market their products. Ediltrudes is still single and has adopted 2 kids.  She started her business in 1998 with the capital of Php 3000. By now, she has her business growing and established. 

She is asking for a CEVI loan of Php 20,000 to buy more coconuts. In this way she will be able to sell the meat to have income. Through her loan she would have more coco shells too, so that she could sell them to "calamay" makers. Her previous work was a gardener but she was not happy about her salary. So she decided to have a business, a coco-shell supply for "calamay" makers.

CEVI helps Ediltrudes sustain her business. She is provided with credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage to make her business grow.

loans.use: To buy more coconuts to sell the shells for making calamay

loans.name: Skola

texts.en:
Skola has had a small salon and small charcoal store in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for two years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $90. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and salon items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan her profit will increase and she will be able to expand her business.

Skola is 28 years old, married, and has two children aged 5 and 7.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and salon items for her business.

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophal S. was born in 1970 and lives in Trapaing Por village in Kampong Cham province. She is a teacher in the local school. Aside from this career, she is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate cassavas. She currently faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to hire laborers to work on the field. She is requesting a loan to hire laborers.

Her husband, Mr. Pao Lim Leang, is a soldier who makes a small salary to support the family. Mrs. Sophal S. has three children, one of whom is attending the local school. The other two children are too young to work or study because they are five years and one year old.

loans.use: To hire laborers to work on the field.

loans.name: Saveth

texts.en: Mrs. Saveth D. is a villager in Bous Knol village in Kampong Cham province. She and her husband, Mr. D. Vandeth, are laborers in the community. They now want to start breeding pigs for income to improve their living conditions. Thus, Mrs. Saveth D. decided to ask for a loan to buy fifteen piglets and build a piggery for her breeding. She hopes to increase their income and improve her family's living conditions. She is 29 years old and the mother of three children who are too young to work or stuD.. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy fifteen piglets and build a piggery for breeding.

loans.name: Furaha Group

texts.en:
Asia has had a small store selling charcoal and firewood in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for many years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $50. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more fuel for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to expand her business. Asia is 27 years old, married, with four children aged 8, 6, 3 and 2.

Asia will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Mwatima, Mwajuma C., Mwanahamis and Mwajuma S.. Each woman has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood for her business.

loans.name: Lin

texts.en: Mrs. Lin S. is 48 years old and she now lives in Kor Kar village in Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables. In this plantation, she can earn less income than is required to provide a better life for her family. Thus, Mrs. Lin S. decided to request a loan to add to her savings to build a house for her family. She is a widow with seven children, three of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To add her saving to build the house for her family living.

loans.name: Chanthorn

texts.en: Mrs. Chanthorn M. lives in the Chhoer Teal Phlos village in Takeo province. She is 33 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is attending the local school while the others are too young to work or study. She is pig breeder, and her husband, Mr. Sor Chea, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. In this plantation, he faces an obstacle because he does not have enough money to purchase a pump machine, fuel, fertilizer, and pesticides to support the field. Thus, Mrs. Chanthorn M. decided to ask for a loan for her husband’s plantation. Her husband is presented with her in the picture.

loans.use: To buy pump machine, fuel, fertilizer, and pesticides to support the field.

loans.name: Maryam

texts.en:
Maryam is a food seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for six years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $60, working every day at her business for six hours.

Maryam is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food materials for her business. She hopes to increase her profits and expand her business.

Maryam is 22 years old, married, and has one child who is six years old.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients for her food business.

loans.name: Nia Moja Group

texts.en:
Siasa is a breads seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar. She has done this work for seven years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $80, working each day for 12 hours. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so she can buy more breads for her business. She is hoping that through this loan she will be able to expand her business, improve her home and pay school fees for her children. Siasa is 46 years old, married, and has three children, 19, 16 and 12 years old. She also cares for one additional dependent.

Siasa will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Bibie, Mwanaisha and Amina. Each woman has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more breads for her business.

loans.name: Edwige

texts.fr: H. Edwige a 26 ans et elle a un enfant qui s’appelle Elisée. Edwige fait la restauration. Edwige vent de pâte, une nourriture béninoise à base de farine de maïs, et le riz, depuis 8 ans. Elle s’approvisionne au Marche Dantokpa, le plus grand marché du Bénin. Actuellement elle connaît la mévente parce que les produits coûtent chers. Elle voudrait ouvrir un maquis ou elle peut vendre les boissons fraiches dans le futur.
texts.en:
Ms. Edwige H. is 26 years old and has a child named Elisée. For eight years, Edwige has been in the catering business, selling pâte (a Beninese food made from cornmeal) and rice. She gets her supplies at the Dantokpa Market, the biggest market in Benin. Presently, she has been experiencing a drop in sales because of high costs. She would like to open a local eatery, where she can sell cold beverages in the future.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies for making food to sell

loans.name: Samira

texts.en:
Samira has a small shop in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for many years. She belongs to the Tawakal kwa Mola group. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $53 and she works for 12 hours each day. She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more rice and oil for her store. She hopes this loan will help her increase her profit and expand her business.

Samira is 36 years old, married, and has four children aged 13, 10, 9 and 3 years.

loans.use: To buy more rice and oil for her store.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita J., a 62-year-old mother from Maribojoc Bohol, sells a variety of goods for a living. She is now a widow and her three children are still dependent on her. She wants to have a quality life for their family, so she joined CEVI because she thinks that the training and insurance services will bring good profits in her business. She knows that that will help her grow her business. She is a previous “Tabo-tabo” vendor. Tabo means “market” in the Cebuano dialect. She earned little profit from selling goods in the market but now she has her own store.

She would like to ask for a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy more inventory for her business. She believes her loan will bring her more profit and income as well.

CEVI is helping Nenita sustain and grow her business. Now, she is provided with credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage to make her business grow.

loans.use: To buy more products to sell in her store

loans.name: Hamisa

texts.en:
Hamisa has a small store of charcoal and is also a bread and rice seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar. She has been in this business for five years, working each day from 12am to 6pm. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $40.

Hamisa is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more charcoal, breads and rice for her business. She is hoping that through this loan she will increase her profit and her business will grow.

Hamisa is 31 years old, married with five children aged 12, 11, 4, 3 and 2.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal, breads and rice for her business.

loans.name: Mwanzo Mgumu Group

texts.en:
Fatma has been selling juice and phone vouchers in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for many years. She earns an average monthly profit of $80. She is requesting this loan from BRAC Tanzania in order to buy more phone vouchers and juice for her business. She hopes that this loan will help her increase her profit and expand her business. Fatma is 40 years old, married with five children aged 19, 17, 15, 13 and 9.

Fatma will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Khadija, who has her own small business selling charcoal and firewood in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more phone vouchers and juice for her business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a thirty-five year old married woman with two children. For the past four years, Mary has been selling maize and ‘gari’. Gari is produced from cassava and it is high in carbohydrates. She obtains her supplies from the farming communities and retails to her customers. She wants to use the loan to buy maize and gari in bulk to meet the daily demands of her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to pay her children’s educational fees.

Mary is a member of a community group called "To God be the Glory" Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To procure ‘gari’ for re-sale

loans.name: Mohammad Nahim

texts.en:
M. Nahim is the son of M. A.. He lives in district 8th, Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and has 4 children. He is a tailor and works hard to earn money to meet his family’s requirements. He needs to buy a new sewing machine for his shop because he is having lots of problems with his old machine. He would like to hire a student to help support and increase his business.

He wants to make an individual loan of 40000 Afghani for a term of 8 months and he is very glad to have the chance to expand his business.

loans.use: Buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr:
Fatou S. est une brave commerçante qui tient un shop au marché central Saint Maures des Fossés. Cette veuve vend divers articles et entretient sa famille.
Elle sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer son commerce.
texts.en:
Fatou S. is an honest tradeswoman with a shop in the Saint Maures des Fossés central market. She is a widow supporting her family, and she sells various items. Madame S. is requesting this loan to grow her business.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To grow her business

loans.name: Benoit

texts.fr:
La signification d’ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique d’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux a 0% d’intérêt aux gens très vulnérables et il est dans un groupe qui lancent bientôt un programme de la microassurance santé. 
 
D. Benoit a 44 ans et il a 2 enfants, Sandra et Justine, les 2 sont scolarisées. Il vend des boissons depuis 20 ans, et il les achète au dépôt de Vodgè, un quartier de Cotonou. Le revenu de ses autres crédits lui a permis de payer les frais de la scolarisation de ses enfants. Dans le futur, il voudrait commencer par vendre aussi les jus de fruits.
texts.en:
Benoit D. is 44 and has 2 children, Sandra et Justine, both enrolled in school. He has been selling drinks for 20 years, and he buys them in the depot at Vodgè, a neighborhood in Cotonou. The profit he made thanks to his previous loans has permitted him to pay the school fees for his children. In future, he would like to begin selling fruit juice as well.

Benoit is requesting this loan from Kiva partner, Alidé. The meaning of Alidé in the local language of Benin, Fon, is "another path always exists for the most poor". Benin is a small country in West Africa beside Nigeria, where the GNP per capita is US$ 1,500. Alidé offers special 0% interest loans to very vulnerable clients and it is in a group which will soon be beginning a micro health insurance program.


Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of drinks for re-sale

loans.name: Suvonkul

texts.en:
B. Suvonkul is 56 years old. He is married and has 5 children. Mr. Suvonkul was born in a simple rural family and has worked with livestock for 30 years. He is very experienced and has special skills in livestock care that help him to develop his business. He raises and sells livestock and sells meat and milk. Suvonkul is requesting a loan of $800 USD to enable him purchase a second dairy cow. The second cow will enable him increase the milk produced and will provide income security to the family when one of the cows is in-calf. The income will enable Suvonkul provide for his family, take good care of his cows and supply his neighbors with quality milk.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing cattle for expanding the business.

loans.name: Chia Rose

texts.en:
Rose was born on July 24th, 1972. Through unmarried, she is blessed with one child, who is under 15 years of age.  She is a hard working lady and has faced so many challenges in life such as being unable to get married, ill health and  being unable to take care of her only son. Due to all of these challenges she made up her mind to become a GHAPE member in 2007. In this same year, she received her pioneer loan of 40,000FRS, and her repayments were made promptly. 

With a loan of 100,0000FRS, she plans to buy 7 cases of corn, 5 cases of beans, 4 cases of garri, and 5 buckets of coco yams. The loan repayment will start on the day the loan is disbursed . She is sure the business will succeed because she has been doing this activity for long period of time. She is has a good site for this particular business and she has a lot of customers. Her neighbors are happy with the business that she is doing because their travel distance to the market is reduced and the can buy from her late in the night. She plans to use her profits to reinvest into the business, to cater for her son's needs and to give good medical attention to her self and her son. She prefer to borrow from GHAPE because of the social services that GHAPE offers, and the method of repayment is comfortable.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: buy and sell of corn, beans, garri, cocoyams and dressmaking services.

loans.name: Alima

texts.en: Alima G., 45, is married and has five children in high school. Alima lives with her family at Madina, in Ghana. She runs a small provisions store in her neighborhood. She has been in business for twelve years. Alima buys her goods from wholesalers in the city and treks to markets in nearby towns. She says that she also supplies her products to other food vendors in her community. Alima would like to have a larger working capital. She wants to buy goods in bulk whenever she travels to the city to save her the problem of frequent trips. Alima is in a loan group called “Miracle”. The group members guarantee each another as collateral to insure the loan.

loans.use: To procure provisions

loans.name: Adelfa

texts.en:
Adelfa E. is a scrap buyer. Everyday, she goes out on the streets to buy scrap materials like metals, cans, bottles etc. From the garbage that she gets from the households, she earns money to make a living. She started her business in 1996 with a capital of Php 2,000. Now,  her business is growing and established. She has one child and dreams of sending her to school. The business that she has right now is a big help for the family income.

She is requesting a loan of Php 9,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy more scrap and sell it to her clients. The loan will allow Adelfa to earn more profits for her family.

CEVI is supporting Adelfa with her business. She now enjoys credit assistance trainings and insurance services with CEVI.

loans.use: To buy more scrap for resale

loans.name: Mir Habibullah

texts.en:
Mir Habibullah is 55 years old. He lives in district 12 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He has eight children and lives in a big family. He has got a general store in which he sells various kinds of things. He wants to expand his business and buy more goods, especially the things that are most in demand. On the other hand, he wants to attract more customers.
He has requested an individual loan of 30,000 Afghani for a term of 12 months. He is happy that there is this nice process of small loans that can solve the entrepreneurs’ problems.

loans.use: buying more inventory for his little store

loans.name: Yemalin Marie

texts.fr:
La signification d’ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique d’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux a 0% d’intérêt aux gens très vulnérables et il est dans un groupe qui lancent bientôt un programme de la microassurance santé. 
 
H. Yemalin Marie  a 42 ans et elle s’est mariée avec BOSSOU Euphrem. Ils ont  quatre enfants – Stefane, Patrick, Mathias et Cherita. Elle vend les savons et les fruits depuis 25 ans ; et ils les achètent au Marche Dantokpa, le marche central de l’Afrique d’Ouest. Avec les revenus de son activité, elle a pu épargner et aider son mari dans les charges du foyer. Dans l’avenir elle voudrait vendre les divers.
texts.en:
Yemalin Marie H., 42, is married to Euphrem Bossou. They have 4 children, Stefane, Patrick, Mathias, and Cherita. She has been selling soap and fruit for 25 years, buying her products at Marché Dantokpa, the central market of West Africa. With the income from her business, she has been able to put aside some savings and help her husband support the household. In future, she would like to be able to sell diverse merchandise. The loan she is requesting is through Kiva field partner, Alidé.

The meaning of Alidé in the local language of Benin, Fon, is "another path always exists for the most poor". Benin is a small country in West Africa beside Nigeria, where the GNP per capita is US$ 1,500. Alidé offers special 0% interest loans to very vulnerable clients and it is in a group which will soon be beginning a micro health insurance program.


Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of fruit and soap for re-sale

loans.name: Ablaye

texts.fr:
Ablaye S. produit du charbon de bois qu'il vend aux ménages. Cet exploitant forestier basé à Bignona, au nord de Ziguinchor, a une expérience du secteur.
Grâce à cette activité il arrive à subvenir aux besoins de sa famille restée au village. Il sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer son activité.
texts.en:
Ablaye S. makes charcoal and retails it to households. This forest worker based in Bignona, north of Ziguinchor, has some experience in his field.

Thanks to this business, he manages to support his family who have stayed behind in the village. He is requesting this loan to bolster his business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Production

loans.name: Valerie Alida

texts.fr:
La signification d’ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique d’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux a 0% d’intérêt aux gens très vulnérables et il est dans un groupe qui lancent bientôt un programme de la microassurance santé. 
 
D. Valerie Alida s’est mariée avec BOSSOU Nicolas. Ils ont 3 enfants :  Audrey, Franky et Chilsain. Deux sont scolarisés et un n’a pas encore l’ âge d’aller à l’école. Depuis 20 ans il vend les chaussures et le charbon de bois. Les revenus de ses autres crédits lui ont permis d’aider dans les charges du foyer. Dans le futur elle voudrait ajouter la vente de plastiques à ses activités.
texts.en:
Valerie Alida D. is married to Nicolas Bossou. They have 3 children: Audrey, Franky, et Chilsain. Two are enrolled in school and the third is still too young to go to school. For 20 years, she has been selling shoes and charcoal. The profit from her previous loans has allowed her to help support her family. In future, she would like to add plastics sales to her business. The loan that she is requesting is through Kiva field partner, Alidé.

The meaning of Alidé in the local language of Benin, Fon, is "another path always exists for the most poor". Benin is a small country in West Africa beside Nigeria, where the GNP per capita is US$ 1,500. Alidé offers special 0% interest loans to very vulnerable clients and it is in a group which will soon be beginning a micro health insurance program.


Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of shoes for re-sale

loans.name: Amina

texts.en: Amina is the daughter of A. and lives in the first district of Kabul, Afghanistan. She lives together with her husband and two of her children who are students. Her husband has a metal shop. He is a hard-working man and tries to give his family a comfortable life and educate their children. Amina wants to take an individual loan of 42,000 Afghani for a term of 12 months. Through the loan, her husband wants to expand his business and to buy some essential tools which can make his work easier.

loans.use: Buying essential tools for her husband's shop

loans.name: Monique

texts.fr:
La signification d’ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique d’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux a 0% d’intérêt aux gens très vulnérables et il est dans un groupe qui lancent bientôt un programme de la microassurance santé. 
 
S.  a 41 ans. Elle est allée à l'école jusqu'au lycée et elle a trois enfants. Les 3 enfants sont scolarisés: Florel, Asriel et Joresee. Depuis 8 ans elle fait la restauration. Elle vend aussi de boissons. Elle vend les matins la pâte,une nourriture locale à base de farine de maïs, les produits de la brasserie, l’eau fraiche et du riz préparé. Actuellement elle connaît la mévente, mais dans l’avenir elle voudrait commencer par vendre aussi dans le soir.
texts.en:
Monique S., 41, was able to attend school up to high school. She has 3 children, Florel, Asriel et Joresee, all three of whom are enrolled in school. For eight years, she has been running a small restaurant. She also sells drinks. In the morning, she sells porridge, a local dish made from corn (maize), brewed drinks, water, and cooked rice. Presently, she is in a period of slowing sales, but in future, she would like to sell evenings as well. The loan that she is requesting is through Kiva field partner, Alidé.

The meaning of Alidé in the local language of Benin, Fon, is "another path always exists for the most poor". Benin is a small country in West Africa beside Nigeria, where the GNP per capita is US$ 1,500. Alidé offers special 0% interest loans to very vulnerable clients and it is in a group which will soon be beginning a micro health insurance program.


Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of foodstuffs used in preparing cooked food

loans.name: Gisèle

texts.fr:
La signification d’ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique d’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux a 0% d’intérêt aux gens très vulnérables et il est dans un groupe qui lancent bientôt un programme de la microassurance santé. 
 
Gisèle a 36 ans et elle s’est mariée avec ANAGO Firmin. Ils ont 4 enfants : Frida, Purderria, Doriane et Naomie. Tous sont scolarisés. Gisèle est coiffeuse depuis 10 ans et elle vend également  les produits cosmétiques. Ses autres crédits lui ont permis d’augmenter son niveau d’activité. Dans la futur, elle voudrait commencer par acheter ses marchandises en gros.
texts.en:
The meaning of Alidé in the local Fon language of Benin is, "there is always a path for the poorest of people." Benin is a small country in Western Africa, bordering with Nigeria, where GDP per capita is $1,500. Alidé (Kiva Field Partner) offers special loans with 0% interest to highly vulnerable people, and belongs to a group that is soon to launch a micro health insurance program. Gisèle A. is 36 years old and is married to Firmin Anago. They have four children: Frida, Purderria, Doriane and Naomie, all of whom have attended school. Gisèle has been a hairdresser for ten years and she also sells cosmetic products. Her other loans have allowed her to increase her business activities, and in the future she would like to start buying her goods wholesale.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetic products

loans.name: Senablodo Petronille

texts.fr:
La signification d’ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique d’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux a 0% d’intérêt aux gens très vulnérables et il est dans un groupe qui lancent bientôt un programme de la microassurance santé. 
 
A. Z. Senablodo Petronille a 37 ans. Elle est scolarisée jusqu’au lycée. Petronille  a un enfant, Alvarex ; il a 10 ans et il va l’école.  Petronille vend les bijoux depuis 12 ans et les tissus depuis 10 ans. Petronille s’approvisionne a Lomé au Togo et au Marche Dantokpa, le plus grand marché de Cotonou, Benin. Le crédit lui a permis de répondre à ses besoins et les charges de son enfant. Dans l’avenir elle voudrait commencer par vendre en gros.
texts.en:
Ms. Senablodo Petronille A. Z., age 37, was educated through high school and has a son, Alvarex, who is 10 years old and in school. Petronille has been selling jewelry for twelve years and cloth for ten years. She gets her supplies in Lomé, Togo, and at the Dantokpa Market, the largest market in Cotonou, Benin. This loan will enable her to answer the needs and expenses of her child. In the future, she would like to start selling merchandise wholesale.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small country in West Africa, next to Nigeria, and it has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans at an interest rate of 0% to highly vulnerable people. It is part of a group that will soon launch a micro health insurance program.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloth, jewelry, and shoes for resale

loans.name: Sayed Sahadudin

texts.en: S. Sahadudin is 35 years old. He lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He has got a general store and all the family members benefit from the income he generates. He wants to expand his business and to attract more customers, so he has requested an individual loan of 50,000 Afghani for a term of 10 months. He is happy that he has got the chance to progress as soon as possible.

loans.use: Completing the inventory of his general store

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy S. is thirty-seven years old. She is married with three children. Lucy is resourceful and enterprising. She has sent three children all the way through high school with her business earnings. She operates a local restaurant and sells local foods like “fufu” and “banku”. Fufu is prepared from pounded cassava and plantains, taken with soup. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains, and it is taken with hot pepper or soup. 

Lucy says prices of raw materials have gone up significantly and she is no longer able to meet her production expenditure. She needs the loan to enable her to inject additional capital into the business to scale up production and maintain quality as well. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like maize, cassava, plantains, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood. Lucy is a member of a group called “Miracle” Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee and provide support to one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy food stuffs, meat, fish and vegetables to produce cooked food for re-sale

loans.name: Safa

texts.en:
Sara R. is currently in the business of selling beans and rice at a little hotel and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Sara is 26 years old and is married to a husband who is a policeman. She has 3 children, and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Cica Irène

texts.fr:
La signification d’ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique d’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux a 0% d’intérêt aux gens très vulnérables et il est dans un groupe qui lancent bientôt un programme de la microassurance santé. 
 
A. Z. Cica Irène fait la couture et la vente de pagnes et bijoux depuis 11 ans. Irène a une fille qui s’appelle Dorone et qui va l’école. Les crédits passés lui ont permis de faire ses achats en gros a Lomé au Togo et de supporter la scolarisation de son enfant. Dans le futur elle voudrait ouvrir une boutique et vendre également des chaussures.
texts.en:
Cica Irène A. Z. is a seamstress and has been selling pagnes (colorful West African cloth) and jewelry for eleven years. She has a daughter named Dorone, who goes to school. Past loans have enable Ms. A. Z. to do her buying wholesale in Lomé, Togo, and to support her child’s schooling. In the future, she would like to open a shop and to sell shoes too.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small country in West Africa, next to Nigeria, and it has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans at an interest rate of 0% to highly vulnerable people. It is part of a group that will soon launch a micro health insurance program.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloth and jewelry for resale

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
"Emma", as he is popularly called is forty-eight years old. He is married with two kids and very hard-working. Emmanuel is a dealer in electrical goods such as assorted lights, electrical cables, extension plugs, wires, electric lamps, speakers, transistors, screw drivers, wires, television cords, antennas, etc. He buys his supplies from importers at wholesale prices and sells to his customers at retail prices.

Emmanuel is requesting the loan to enable him to procure increased stocks of electrical and electronic parts. He hopes to increase his savings to expand his shop to include refrigerators. He would be very grateful for your support. He has been in this business for the past eight years and has a lot of experience and a wide market share in his business area. He belongs to the community group called Miracle Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee and support one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To procure electrical goods for re-sale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary S. is currently in the business of selling local brew at a bar and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Mary is 42 years old and is widowed. She has 3 children, and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business>

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Chantal

texts.fr:
La signification d’ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique d’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux a 0% d’intérêt aux gens très vulnérables et il est dans un groupe qui lancent bientôt un programme de la microassurance santé. 
 
K. Chantal a 43 ans et elle a 4 enfants qui s’appellent Cervne, Mraain, Rosone, Yocovona. Trois enfants sont scolarisés et un est à l’apprentissage. Chantal vend les divers et les vivres comme le maïs, le riz, les haricots, l’huile d’arachide et les divers depuis 17 ans. Chantal achète ses produits au Marche Tokpa, le marché central de l’Afrique d’Ouest  et à la gare de Gbegamey, un quartier de Cotonou, Bénin. Dans le futur, Chantal voudrait commencer par vendre les sacs de riz.
texts.en:
Ms. Chantal K. is 43 years old and has four children named Cervne, Mraain, Rosone, and Yocovona. Three of them are in school and one is in an apprenticeship. For seventeen years, Chantal has been selling various goods and staple foods, such as corn, rice, beans, peanut oil, and more. She does her buying at the Tokpa Market, the central marketplace of West Africa, and at the station in Gbegamey, a district in Cotonou, Benin. In the future, she would like to start selling sacks of rice.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small country in West Africa, next to Nigeria, and it has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans at an interest rate of 0% to highly vulnerable people. It is part of a group that will soon launch a micro health insurance program.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various good, rice, beans, corn, and peanut oil

loans.name: Augustus

texts.en: Augustus T. is fifty-one years old. He is divorced with three children. Two of his children are working and the last child is currently at the university. Augustus is a dealer in building materials such as cement, nails, roofing sheets, etc. at Madina market. He buys his supplies from importers at Accra Central, at wholesale prices, and sells to his customers at retail prices. He is requesting the loan to enable him to procure increased amounts of goods to accelerate his business. With the loan, he hopes to increase his savings to expand his shop. He would be very grateful for your support. He belongs to the community group called Miracle Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee and support one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To procure building materials

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret K. is currently in the business of selling pits and onions and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Margret is 27 years old and married. Her husband is a watchman. She has two children who both go to school. With the extra capital from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her business selling pits and onions.

loans.name: Séraphine

texts.fr:
La signification d’ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique d’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux a 0% d’intérêt aux gens très vulnérables et il est dans un groupe qui lancent bientôt un programme de la microassurance santé. 
 
C. Séraphine s’est marie avec BOTIN Prosper et ils ont quatre enfants qui s’appellent Ken, Morelle, Junior, et Adjoui. Tous sont scolarises. Elle vend la nourriture comme le riz, et le macaroni depuis 10 ans. Séraphine s’approvisionne a Dantokpa, le marche central en Afrique d’Ouest, et ses derniers crédits l’ont aidés dans les frais du foyer. Dans l’avenir, elle voudrait commencer par vendre les boissons fraiches.
texts.en:
The meaning of Alidé in the local Fon language of Benin is, "there is always a path for the poorest of people." Benin is a small country in Western Africa, bordering with Nigeria, where GDP per capita is $1,500. Alidé (Kiva Field Partner) offers special loans with 0% interest to highly vulnerable people, and belongs to a group that is soon to launch a micro health insurance program. Séraphine C. is married to Prosper Botin and they have four children called Ken, Morelle, Junior and Adjoui, all of whom have attended school. Séraphine has sold food such as rice and macaroni for ten years. She stocks up at Western Africa’s central market, Dantokpa. Her previous loans have helped her out with household expenses. In the future she would like to start selling cold drinks.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, macaroni and drinks

loans.name: Abdurazok

texts.en:
A. Abdurazok is 45 years old. He is married with three children. Abdurazok is providing taxi services with his car. He has been in this business for the last 7 years. Abdurazok is always trying to provide high quality services at attractive prices. He is doing his best to make his business stable and profitable as he is the main bread-winner in his large family. He is ready to work from the early morning till late at night in order to keep his customers and obtain new ones. Today he is planning to replace the fuel supply system with one using gas, as gas is cheaper than petrol. For this reason he requests $800 US Dollars for the term of 10 months. He thanks everyone supporting him and promises to repay the loan in a timely manner.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing a kapron gas-cylinder for a fuel supply system for his taxi.

loans.name: Kwadwo

texts.en:
Kwadwo O. is divorced and the father of one child. He is a 35-year-old businessman. He owns a boutique and sells men’s wear such as suits, shirts and trousers, shoes, belts, and caps. He has been in business for the past fifteen years.

O. says he purchases his stock from major wholesale outlets in Accra. He wants to inject more working capital into his business to enable him to purchase bulk quantities during his trips. With the loan, he believes he could have the resources to purchase good quality stock to satisfy his customers. He hopes that he can increase his profit margin substantially to enable him to support his family, especially the education of his child.

O. is in a group called Strong Trust Bank in his community. The members in the group guarantee for one another as collateral to access the loan and provide support and assistance to one another in handling repayment.

loans.use: To procure men’s wear for re-sale

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose L. is currently in the business of selling cold drinks at the hotel. Rose is 40 years old and widowed. She has five children and all her children go to school. She is requesting a loan to expand the business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. loans.use: To expand her business selling cold drinks.

loans.name: Mahmudjon

texts.en:
Mahmudjon is a very hard-working and responsible entrepreneur. He and his family live in Isfara, Tajikistan. He is married and has a daughter. Mahmudjon works in the central city market selling kids' shoes and clothing for teenagers. His business is characterized by stability and consistent growth. He has been working in the market for 6 years.

Once a month he travels to the neighboring city of Istaravshan to purchase new goods. Mahmudjon likes to work for himself. His business has been the main source of income for his whole family. Today Mahmudjon would like to ask for a loan of $1000 USD for the term of 10 months to purchase new clothing and shoes to sell. We believe Mahmudjon’s drive for success will help this young entrepreneur succeed and thrive in business. You can be an important part of the growth of Mahmudjon’s business.

loans.use: Purchasing new clothing to sell

loans.name: Sayohat

texts.en:
Problems and money shortages never defeated Sayohat, who has always looked for a way to get past obstacles and continue to improve her situation. Sayohat is an extremely hard-working and energetic woman. She is 39 years old, married and the loving mother of three children. Sayohat started her own business because her husband’s salary was not enough for their family expenses. For more than 5 years, she has operated a store where she sells kids' and women’s clothing. Her store is well known, and people love to visit because it's clean, tidy, and run by someone who is very kind and thoughtful. Sayohat hopes that her store will keep growing so that she can maintain a comfortable life for her family especially for her children. To make that possible, she has applied for a new loan that she will use to buy more clothing to sell. With this purpose Sayohat requests $1000 USD for the term of 10 months. She promises to repay the loan in time and thanks everyone supporting her.

texts.en:

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose N. is currently in the business of selling bread, eggs, and cakes at the market. Rose is 35 years old and married. Her husband is a clerk in the Ministry of Education. She has three children who all go to school. She is requesting a loan to expand the business.

loans.use: To expand her business selling food at the market.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary Mavis N. is seventy-two years old. She is a widow and has three children who are all living independently. Mavis is a dealer in hardware: assorted paints, nails, roofing sheets, hammers, PVC pipes, etc. at Haatso, a suburb of Accra where she lives with her grandchildren. She buys her supplies from importers in Accra at wholesale prices and sells to her customers at retail prices.

Mary is requesting the loan to enable her to procure increased stocks of paints, nails, hammers etc., to accelerate business progress. With the loan, she hopes to increase savings to expand her shop to include the sale of cement. She would be very grateful for your support.

Mary is in a group in her community called Strong Trust Bank. The members in the group guarantee for one another as collateral to access the loan and provide support and assistance to one another in handling repayment.

loans.use: To procure hardware for re-sale

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Dina J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and cosmetics in her shop. Dina is 30 years old and single. She has no children. She is requesting a loan to expand her business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. loans.use: To expand her business selling charcoal and cosmetics.

loans.name: Badenya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes de Badegna sont toutes mariés, âgées de 35 ans en moyenne et mères de 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Ganabougou de la préfecture de Yanfolila (troisième région administrative du Mali).
Ces femmes sont partenaires de Soro Yiriwaso  depuis 2 ans .Elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire. Tous les prêts précédents  ont été correctement  remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau  prêt les femmes comptent acheter, 2 sacs d’ignames,  4 sacs d’oignon séchée de 25kg /sac, 5 sacs de sel et des paquets de cube maggi. Elles s’approvisionnent généralement auprès des commerçantes venant de la république de la  Côte d’Ivoire et cela chaque jour de foire.  
Les marchandises ainsi achetées sont revendues dans le marché journalier de Yanfolila en détail au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée en général de femmes.      
Ces activités commerciales peuvent faire gagner aux femmes en  moyenne une marge bénéficiaire mensuelle de 40.000FCFA. Ce qui leur permet de rembourser l’échéance du prêt et de faire face à certaines dépenses du foyer (santé, éducation, habillement…etc.)
En perspective chacune de ces femmes veut agrandir sa clientèle, se construire une belle maison et assurer le bien être des enfants.
texts.en:
The women of Badegna are all married mothers who average 35 years of age and four children. They live in traditional extended families in the Ganabougou district of Yanfolila prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

These women have been partners of Soro Yiriwaso for two years and are on their third solidarity loan. All the preceding ones have been correctly repaid. With this new loan, they plan to buy two sacks of yams, four 25-kg sacks of dried onions, five sacks of salt, and some packets of Maggie bouillon cubes. Supplies are generally gotten from merchants from the Republic of Cote d’Ivoire each market day. The goods purchased in this way are resold at the Yanfolila daily market at the retail level, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed generally of women.

This commerce can earn the women an average monthly profit margin of 40,000 francs CFA that enables them to make loan payments and to address certain household expenses (health, education, clothing… etc.). Looking forward, each of these women want to expand their customer base, to have a nice house built, and to ensure the well-being of the children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments (dried onions, Maggi cubes, salt) and some yams

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en:
Christiana is a 49-year-old businesswoman. She is divorced with three kids who are in school. She sells students’ foam mattress and pillows. She obtains her supplies from the manufacturers and sells at retail prices. She wants to use the loan to buy more foam mattresses and pillows to increase her stock. Her dream is to expand her business to include additional stock like door mats, bedspreads, curtains, etc., to meet the needs of her customers and make increased income.

Christiana aspires to give her children the best education. She is a member of the community group called Miracle Group. Members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans and peer support to repay.

loans.use: To procure students’ mattresses, pillows, etc. for re-sale

loans.name: Navbahor

texts.en:
Navbahor is a brave married woman who works hard for the good of her four children, and she does so alone. The strict discipline she uses with her children allows her to count on her household’s advice and support in working the fields. Navbahor’s children’s grateful attitude continues to encourage her, and they have gathered many lessons during this time that they can use when they form their own households. What Navbahor urgently needs right now are fertilizers and other chemicals for cultivating her land and to be prepared for the upcoming growing season. Navbahor doesn’t just need good land; she also needs a friendly hand to help her out.

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Dembagnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe  Dembagnouma sont mariés, âgés de  25 à 51 ans, mères de 5 enfants en moyenne et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le quartier Ganabougou de la préfecture de Yanfolila (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes qui font le commerce des articles divers,  sont partenaires de Soro Yiriwaso  depuis 3 ans .Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de groupe. Tous les prêts précédents  ont été correctement  remboursés.
Les femmes veulent acheter, 10 pièces de pagnes wax et une importante quantité de produits cosmétiques (du parfum, des crèmes pour la peau etc.). Elles s’approvisionnent  à Bamako (capitale du Mali) auprès de divers grossistes dans leur spécialisation. Elles vendent en détail, au comptant et à crédit, les produits cosmétiques et les tissus (découpés en plusieurs  « 3 pagnes ») à Yanfolila à une clientèle essentiellement composée de femmes. Ces activités commerciales peuvent faire gagner aux femmes en  moyenne une marge bénéficiaire mensuelle de 40.000FCFA. Ce qui leurs permet de rembourser l’échéance du prêt et de faire face à certaines dépenses du foyer (santé, éducation, habillement…etc.)
En perspective chacune de ces femmes veut agrandir sa clientèle, posséder une boutique et ajouter d’autres articles.
texts.en:
The members of the group Dembagnouma are 25 to 51 years old, married and have on average 5 children. They live in traditional extended families in the neighborhood of Ganabougou in the préfecture of Yanfolila (Third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

These women sell various items and have been partners of Soro Yiriwaso for 3 years. This is their fifth group loan. All the previous loans have been fully reimbursed.

The women want to buy 10 pieces of Wax brand pagnes [traditional wrap around cloth] and a considerable quantity of cosmetic products (perfume, body cream etc...). They stock up in Bamako (The capital of Mali) at specialized wholesalers. They sell retail the cosmetic products and the fabric (cut up in several pieces "3 pagnes"), for cash or credit, in Yanfolila to customers who are mostly women. These commercial activities enable the women to make on average a monthly benefit of 40, 000 FCFA [about USD 78].

This allows them to reimburse their loan and cope with some of the household expenses (Health, education, clothing, etc...). In the future, each one of these women would like to increase their clientele, own a shop and add on other items.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabric and cosmetic products

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora D. is currently in the business of selling perfume at the market street. Flora is 37 years old and married. Her husband is a teacher. She has four children and they all go to school. She is requesting a loan to expand the business.

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Sabougnouma sont mariées, âgées de  25 à 55 ans, mères de 4 enfants en moyenne et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le quartier Ganabougou de Yanfolila (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes sont partenaires de Soro Yiriwaso  depuis 2 ans .Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt après avoir correctement  remboursées les trois précédents.
Avec ce prêt les femmes achètent chaque semaine, 1 sac de gros mil (sorgho), de la levure, du bois de chauffe et d’autres ingrédients pour la préparation de la bière locale. Les femmes s’entraident pour faire ce travail qui  demande l’utilisation d’une quantité importante de bois de chauffage, d’eau et beaucoup d’attention pour que le résultat donne une boisson de qualité. Elles gagnent chacune 10.000 FCFA dans la vente de la boisson par semaine. La grande vente se fait les jours de foire pendant lesquels affluent les villageois environnants.    
Cette activité permet aux femmes du groupe Sabougnouma de réaliser en   moyenne une marge bénéficiaire mensuelle de 40.000FCFA. Ce qui leur permet de rembourser l’échéance du prêt et de faire face à certains besoins du foyer (santé, éducation, habillement…etc.
texts.en:
The women of the group Sabougnouma are married mothers 25 to 55 years old who have four children on average. They live in traditional extended families in the Ganabougou district of Yanfolila (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

These women have been partners of Soro Yiriwaso for two years and are on their fourth solidarity loan after having correctly repaid the three preceding ones. With this new loan, the women buy each week: one sack of big millet (sorghum), some leavening, firewood, and other supplies for making the local beer. The women help one another in this work, which demands a sizable quantity of firewood, water, and a lot of attention, so as to produce a quality beverage.

They each earn 10,000 francs CFA in selling the beverage each week. The biggest sales are made on market days, during which villagers from surrounding areas abound. This business enables the women of the group to realize an average monthly profit margin of 40,000 francs allowing them to make loan payments and to address certain household needs (health, education, clothing… etc.).

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for making the local beer

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:

loans.name: Sinignèssigui Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe  Sinignèssigui sont mariés, âgés de  25 à 65 ans et mères de 5 enfants en moyenne. Ils vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le quartier Bounoukobougou de la préfecture de Yanfolila (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes sont partenaires de Soro Yiriwaso  depuis 5 ans et font le petit commerce de condiments alimentaires et de céréales. Elles sont à leur neuvième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe) et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien  remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt les femmes comptent acheter, 200 kg  d’arachide pour préparer de la pâte d’arachide, 50 kg d’oignons frais, 50 kg de graines de néré pour la préparation du soumbala, 500kg de maïs, 200kg de sorgho et 100kg de petit mil. Elles s’approvisionnent auprès des paysans producteurs et effectuent leurs ventes en détail au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle essentiellement constituée de femmes.   
Ces activités permettent aux femmes du groupe Sinignèssigui de réaliser en   moyenne une marge bénéficiaire mensuelle de 50.000FCFA. Ce qui leurs permet de rembourser l’échéance du prêt et de faire face à certains besoins du foyer (santé, éducation, habillement…etc.)
texts.en:
The members of the Sinignèssigui group are married, aged between 25 and 65, and have an average of five children each. They live in traditional extended families in the Bounoukobougou neighborhood of the Yanfolila prefecture (Mali’s third administrative region). The women have been partners of Soro Yiriwaso for five years and have a small business selling spices and cereals. They are on their ninth solidarity loan (group loan) and all previous loans were fully repaid. The women plan to use this loan to buy 200 kg of peanuts for making peanut butter, 50 kg of fresh onions, 50 kg of néré seeds for preparing soumbala, 500 kg of corn, 200 kg of sorghum and 100 kg of millet. They get their supplies from local producers and sell them at retail for cash or credit to a clientele consisting mainly of women. The business allows the women of the Sinignèssigui group to make an average profit of CFA 50,000/month. With this they are able to repay the loan and meet some of the needs of their household (health, education, clothing, etc.).

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various food items

loans.name: Awa Yombé

texts.fr: Awa Yombé D. est une femme mariée, avec 02 enfants dont elle a la charge. Elle veut, avec ce prêt renforcer son commerce de produits cosmétiques et habillement. Elle pourrait ainsi accroître ses revenus pour mieux participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de sa famille
texts.en:
Awa Yombé D. is a married woman with two children who are in her care. She wants to use this loan to boost her commerce in cosmetics and clothing. She would thus be able to grow her revenues to do better in covering day-to-day family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy goods wholesale: fabrics and clothing for resale

loans.name: Rebbecca

texts.en:
Rebbecca W. is currently in the business of selling ice cream at the market street, on occasional days, and at the stadiums. Rebbecca is 34 years old and single. She has no children. She is requesting a loan to expand the business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her business selling ice cream.

loans.name: Djiguissèmè Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djiguissèmè de l’association Djiguignouman sont au nombre de quatre (trois mariées et une veuve). Elles vivent dans des familles monogamiques avec en moyenne 28 ans et  2 enfants dans le village de Ségou coura Bamanan (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles sont toutes membres d’une même association traditionnelle et font les activités de commerce d’articles divers (pagnes, savon, ustensiles de cuisine, céréales et fruits et légumes etc.). 
C’est dans leurs recherches de ressources financières complémentaires qu’elles ont fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur 1er prêt de groupe (prêt solidaire).
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter 12 douzaines de tasses inoxydables, 24 pièces  de pagnes wax (tissus très prisés en Afrique de l’ouest) et 13 cartons de savon de lessive. Elles s’approvisionnent auprès des grossistes au grand marché de Ségou pour l’ensemble de ces articles qui sont revendus au marché du château de la ville de Ségou puis en ambulant dans les quartiers du village de Ségou coura, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle majoritairement composée de femmes.
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 23 800FCA qui sera épargné et  utilisé pour la prise en charge des frais scolaires des enfants.
texts.en:
There are four women in the Djiguissèmè group from the Djiguignouman association (three are married and one is a widow). They live in monogamous families in the village of Ségou Coura Bamana (Mali's fourth administrative region) and have an average age of 28 and an average of two children each. They all belong to the same traditional association and have a business selling miscellaneous items (traditional African cloth, soap, cooking utensils, cereal, fruit, nuts, etc.). In their search for additional financing, they turned to the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their first group (i.e. solidarity) loan with the institution. The loan will be used to buy 12 dozen stainless steel bowls, 24 pieces of waxed cloth (highly regarded in West Africa) and 13 boxes of laundry soap. Most of their supplies come from wholesalers at the main market in Ségou, and they sell them either at the Château market (also in Ségou) or by walking around the neighborhoods of the village of Ségou-Coura to a clientele consisting mainly of women who pay cash or buy on credit. The women hope to make a monthly profit of CFA 23,800 which they will save up and use to pay for their children’s school fees.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bowls, waxed cloth and soap

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal. Veronica is 39 years old and divorced. She has four children and all her children go to school. She is requesting a loan to expand the business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her business selling charcoal.

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina is 35 years old and she lives in Cimislia district, Gradiste village. The main activity of the borrower is growing cereals and grain legumes.
