Les membres du groupe DANAYA (composé de 7 femmes  mariées)  ont une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans avec en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles résident dans le quartier  Ouayerma de la ville de sikasso.
Les femmes de ce groupe  exercent des activités commerciales différentes mais la plus dominante est la vente de condiments alimentaires à laquelle s’ajoute la vente d’huile, des habits et divers petits articles.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Les deux  prêts précédents a été correctement remboursés.
Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt  4 paquets de condiments alimentaires, 5 bidons de 20 litres d’huile alimentaire,  et 10 douzaine d’habits pour enfants. Elles s’approvisionnent sur place à Sikasso ville et à Bamako (capitale du Mali) auprès des producteurs et des commerçants grossistes.
Les produits sont vendus en détail et la plupart au comptant dans le marché de la ville de Sikasso, dans les quartiers et certains marchés des villages avoisinants avec une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 17.500fcfa par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Danaya group (composed of 7 married women) have an average age of 30 with on average, 3 children. They live in the Ouayerma district of the town of Sikasso.

The women of this group have varied commercial activities but the main one is selling condiments, as well as oil, clothing and various smaller items.

They work with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso so as to satisfy the needs of their clientele. They are on their third solidarity loan (group loan). The two preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

With this loan they expect to buy 4 packets of condiments, 5 jerry cans of 20 liters of cooking oil, and 10 dozen outfits for children. They do their buying right in the town of Sikasso and in Bamako (the capital of Mali) from agricultural producers and commercial wholesalers.

Their merchandise is sold retail and mostly for cash in the market of the town of Sikasso, in the neighborhoods and certain markets of the neighboring villages, to a clientele composed of women and men.

They each hope to make an average profit of 17,500 F CFA monthly, of which part will be used to support the family and the rest re-invested into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments, cooking oil, and clothing for re-sale

loans.name: Maiha Zakhem Group

texts.en:
Asia Kasimu, 34, is married with no children. She sells soft drinks. She started this business in 2002 and works daily from 9am until 11pm. She is able to earn a monthly profit of around US$ 311.

This will be Asia’s seventh loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to increase her stock and bought a fridge. She has repaid the loans successfully. She now hopes for this seventh loan but has not planned what she reA. wants to do with her share. Asia will share this loan with her loan group, "Maisha Zakhem", which totals 16 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Asia is 1st from left, standing, second row.

loans.use: To reinforce the working capital of the various businesses

loans.name: Marie Rose

texts.fr:
La signification d’ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique d’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux a 0% d’intérêt aux gens très vulnérables et il est dans un groupe qui lancent bientôt un programme de la microassurance santé. 
 
A. Marie Rose a 53 ans et elle s’est mariée avec SOSSAGBETO Rémi. Ils ont cinq enfants, Pelague, 1 an, Ruth, 2 ans, Obed, 3 ans, Armedinego, 4 ans, et Israel, 5 ans. Ses enfants sont tous à l’école. Depuis 35 ans Marie Rose est couturière et depuis 15 ans elle vend les pagnes, une vêtement colorée traditionnelle béninoise. Marie Rose s’approvisionne à Lomé, Togo et au Marché Dantokpa, et elle voudrait augmenter son niveau d’activité dans le futur.
texts.en:
Marie Rose A. is 53 years old and married to Rémi SOSSAGBETO. They have five children - Pelague (1 year old), Ruth (2 years old), Obed (3 years old), Armedinego (4 years old), and Israel (5 years old). Her children are all in school. For 35 years, Marie Rose has been a dressmaker, and she has been selling pagnes - traditional brightly coloured Beninese clothing - for 15 years. Marie Rose supplies herself in Lomé, Togo, and at the Marché Dantokpa, and she would like to increase the size of her business in the future. The meaning of ALIDE in the local language of Benin, Fon, is "there is always a path for the poorest." Benin is a small country in West Africa next to Nigeria, and its GDP per capita is $1,500. ALIDE offers special zero-interest loans to highly vulnerable people, and it is part of a group that will soon launch a micro health insurance program.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pagnes (traditional Beninese clothing)

loans.name: Joaquin

texts.es:
El Sr. Joaquin N. B., cliente que se dedica a la construcción, realiza trabajos de albañilería, plomería y carpintería, tiene actualmente un contrato en la población de Coroico, él sale cada semana a ver a su familia, tambien  trabaja en arreglo de viviendas por la zona donde vive.
El Sr. Joaquin tiene casa propia y una familia compuesta por la esposa y dos hijos en edad escolar. La esposa trabaja como empleada del hogar en una casa de Los Pinos, y los fines de semana trabaja en una chicharroneria cerca de su domicilio.
Hace dos años que trabaja con Emprender, se encuentra en su cuarta secuencia debido a que por su trabajo solicito plazos largos, pero siempre demostró puntualidad y responsabilidad en sus pagos.
texts.en:
Joaquin N. B., a client who works in construction, does work in masonry, plumbing, and carpentry. He currently has a contract in the town of Coroico. He leaves every week to see his family. He also does home repairs in the region where he lives. Joaquin has his own home and a family comprised of his wife and two school-aged children. His wife works as an employee in a home in Los Pinos and on the weekends works at a "chicharroneria" [a type of restaurant] near her home. Joaquin has been working with Emprender for 2 years. He finds himself in his fourth sequence due to the fact that for his work he asks for long installments. However, he always demonstrates punctuality and responsibility in his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw material

loans.name: Anne-Marie

texts.fr:
La signification d’ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique d’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux a 0% d’intérêt aux gens très vulnérables et il est dans un groupe qui lancent bientôt un programme de la microassurance santé. 
 
C. Anne-Marie a 49 ans et elle est scolarisée jusqu’au primaire. Elle a 5 enfants dont 2 sont décédés. Ses enfants s’appellent Arnaud, Hermane, et Laurrinda. Ca fait 20 ans qu’elle a commencé de vendre les produits de beauté et les sacs. Actuellement, elle continue de vendre les produits de beauté et elle a ajouté le divers comme les pâtes alimentaires, les produits concentrés, les sandalettes, et les savons. Anne-Marie était victime de vol et elle avait eu des problèmes d’approvisionnement, pourtant, le revenu de ses autres crédits lui a permis de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. Anne-Marie voudrait changer son lieu d’activité à une boutique plus grande.
texts.en:
The meaning of the word Alide in the local Benin language is "there is always a road for the most poor". Benin is a small country in west Africa, beside Nigeria, where the yearly earning per capita is $1500. Alide offers special loans at 0% interest to the most vulnerable and is involved in a group about to start a micro-assurance health program. Anne-Marie C. is 49 years old and has a primary school education. She had 5 children, though two are deceased. Her children's names are Arnaud, Hermane, and Laurrinda. She started selling beauty products and bags twenty years ago. She continues to sell her beauty products but has added an assortment of items such as food spreads, concentrates, sandels and soaps. Anne-Marie was a robery victum so she had a provisioning problem. However, revenue earned with an earlier loan allowed her to meet the needs of her family. Anne-Marie would like to change the location of her business to a larger shop.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase assorted items

loans.name: Dembagnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe DEMBAGNOUMA (composé de 6  mariées et une célibataire)  ont une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans avec en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles résident dans le quartier  de kaboila II de la ville de sikasso.
Les femmes de ce groupe  exercent des activités commerciales différentes mais la plus dominante est la vente d’orange, d’huile alimentaire, de chaussures et d’igname.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt  10 chargements de charrettes  en orange, 10 douzaines de chaussures, 20 sacs d’igname.
Elles s’approvisionnent sur place à Sikasso, à  Bobo (Burkina Faso) et à  Bamako (capitale du Mali).
Les produits sont vendus en détail et la plupart au comptant dans le marché de la ville de Sikasso, dans le quartier et  dans certains marchés des villages environnants,  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 20 000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour subvenir au besoin de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Dembagnouma group (composed of 6 married women and one unmarried) have an average age of 35 with on average, 2 children. They live in the Kaboila II district of the town of Sikasso.

The women of this group have varied commercial activities but the main one is selling oranges, cooking oil, shoes, and cocoyams.

They work with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso so as to satisfy the needs of their clientele. They are on their 5th solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

With this loan they intend to buy 10 wagon loads of oranges, 10 dozen shoes, and 20 sacks of cocoyams. They do their buying right in Sikasso, in Bobo (Burkina Faso), and in Bamako (capital of Mali). The products are sold retail and mostly for cash in the market of the town of Sikasso, in the neighborhood and in certain markets in nearby villages, to a clientele composed of women and men.

They each hope to make an average profit of 20,000 F CFA monthly, money that will be used to cover family expenses, investing any remainder in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of oranges, shoes, and cocoyams

loans.name: Lys Group

texts.en:
Pierre M. sells clothing and miscellaneous merchandise. He used to sell quick-drying cement for a boat. His working capital was US$ 2500. He had to go out to deliver to his clients who were boat companies in Kinshasa and to look for new ones. It was hard work, but he liked it because it was profitable. He had been in this business since 1986 and it prospered. 

In 1991 and 1993, Pierre was a victim of the lootings. All of his goods were taken away and leaving him bankrupt. After closing his business, Pierre and his family went through hard times and his future became uncertain until 1997 - 1998 when he re-launched his business with a capital of $ 100. 

From 1998 - 2005, many companies closed due to the war and the political and economic instability in Kinshasa. Pierre lost most of his company clients. Pierre decided to change his business into clothing and miscellaneous goods. He started this clothing business in 2005 with a capital of US$ 300. He makes a profit of about US$ 200 per month. Currently, his working capital is US$ 1000. His ambition is to open a clothing shop and travel to Dubai on business. Pierre is 45 years old, married, and the father of two children, 15 and 17, both enrolled in school. He has been with Hope since last September.

loans.use: To reinforce the working capital of the various businesses

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Juliette

texts.fr:
La signification d’ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique d’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux a 0% d’intérêt aux gens très vulnérables et il est dans un groupe qui lancent bientôt un programme de la microassurance santé. 
 
D. Juliette a 41 ans et elle a 2 enfants qui s’appellent Jean de Dieu et Mireille. Ses enfants sont scolarisés. Juliette vend les jouets et les tenues hommes et femmes depuis 15 ans. Récemment elle a ajouté les chaussures hommes et femmes. Elle s’approvisionne au marché des vêtements de Missèbo et à Lomé, Togo. Le revenu des ses autres crédits lui a permis de louer sa propre chambre et de répondre aux ses besoins. Juliette voudrait ouvrir sa propre boutique dans l’avenir.
texts.en:
Juliette D., 41, has two children named Jean de Dieu and Mireille, both enrolled in school. Juliette has been selling toys and men's and women's clothing for 15 years. Recently, she expanded into men's and women's shoes. She does her buying at the clothing markets at Missèbo and in Lomé, Togo. The income from her other loans has allowed her to rent her own room and support herself. In future, Juliette would like to own her own shop.

The meaning of Alidé in the local language of Benin, Fon, is "another path always exists for the most poor". Benin is a small country in West Africa beside Nigeria, where the GNP per capita is US$ 1,500. Alidé offers special 0% interest loans to very vulnerable clients and it is in a group which will soon be beginning a micro health insurance program.


Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of clothing for re-sale

loans.name: Kansé

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Kansé C.  a 31 ans, marié et père de deux (02) enfants. Il réside avec sa famille à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Kansé,  après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est initié aux activités d’achat et de vente d’articles divers de boutique.. Dans ce créneau depuis maintenant vingt cinq (25) ans, il est beaucoup sollicité par sa clienèle pour la qualité de ses produits et dispose de deux boutiques présentement (une pour les Prêts à Porter et une pour les articles divers) à la gare routière de Sikasso.
 Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant quatre (04) mois. Il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Avec ce premier prêt, il compte acheter 10 cartons de biscuit, 5 paquets de boisson NBB, 5 casiers de boisson BRAMALI, 2 carton du thé, 1 sac du sucre, 10 paquets de bonbon, 5 carton de mayonnaise Calvé, 4 cartons du lait en poudre NIDO, 3 casiers de boisson MALTA, 2 cartons de savon, etc.
Il sapprovisionne auprès de commerçants grossistes à Bamako(capitale du Mali) avant de les revendre en détail et au comptant à une clientèle composée généralement des voyageurs et surtout de routiers.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 300 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour subvenir aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Kansé C., 31, married and the father of 2 children, lives with his family in Sanoubougou I, one of the working class neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Mr. Kansé, after having tried various businesses without success, took up buying and selling various items. In this niche for 25 years now, he is in great demand with his clientele because of the quality of his merchandise and he presently has two boutiques (one for ready-to-wear and one for sundry items) at the bus station of Sikasso.

To satisfy his ever-growing clientele, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso four months ago. He is on his first individual loan. With this loan, he intends to buy 10 cases of cookies, 5 packets of NBB drinks, 5 cases of BRAMALI drinks, 2 cases of tea, 1 sack of sugar, 10 packets of bonbons, 5 cases of Calvé mayonnaise, 4 cartons of Nido powdered milk, 3 cases of MALTA drinks, 2 cases of soap, etc.

He does his buying from wholesalers in Bamako (capital of Mali) and sells retail and for cash to a clientele generally made up of travelers and above all transporters. He expects to make, with the help of this loan, a monthly profit of 300,000 F CFA which will be used essentially to support his family and pay the interest on the loan, investing any remainder back into his business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Lucresse

texts.fr:
La signification d’ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique d’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux a 0% d’intérêt aux gens très vulnérables et il est dans un groupe qui lancent bientôt un programme de la microassurance santé. 
 
S. Lucresse a 21 ans et elle s’est mariée avec HOUNKOLA Jules. Ils ont deux enfants, Alex et Doris. Doris est scolarisée. Lucresse a commencé avec la vente des arachides il y a 8 ans, et actuellement elle vend les divers et elle est coiffeuse. Le revenu de ses autres crédits lui a permis de construire son lieu d’activité. Avec ce crédit, elle va acheter les œufs pour vendre. Dans l’avenir, elle voudrait commencer par vendre les produits cosmétiques.
texts.en:
Lucresse S., 21, is married to Jules Hounkola, and they have two children Alex et Doris. Doris is enrolled in school. Lucresse began selling peanuts 8 years ago and presently she is selling various items and working as a hairdresser. The income from her other loans has allowed her to build her own workplace. With this loan, she plans to buy eggs for re-sale. In future, she would like to begin to sell cosmetics.

The meaning of Alidé in the local language of Benin, Fon, is "another path always exists for the most poor". Benin is a small country in West Africa beside Nigeria, where the GNP per capita is US$ 1,500. Alidé offers special 0% interest loans to very vulnerable clients and it is in a group which will soon be beginning a micro health insurance program.


Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various items for re-sale

loans.name: Karim

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Karim S. est un célibataire de 24 ans, il réside  à Hamdallaye, un des quartiers populaires de ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur S. a mené plusieurs activités sans succès. Il  décida alors de s’initier au commerce d’articles divers dans  une boutique devant sa maison d’habitation. Il mène cette activité d’achat et de vente des articles divers (Cigarette, bonbon, allumette, Cheew Gum, lait en poudre, Thé, sucre, savon, etc) il y a maintenant trois (03) ans. Il est beaucoup sollicité par sa clienèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant trois (03) mois avec qui il  est à son premier prêt individuel.
Avec ce premier prêt, il compte acheter 2 cartouches de Cigarettes , 2 carton du thé, 1 sac du sucre, 3 cartons de savon,  5 paquets de bonbon, 10 paquet de Cheew Gum, 20 paquets d’allumette, 10 sacs de riz, etc.
 Il sapprovisionne auprès de commerçants grossistes de la place avant de les revendre.Monsieur S. vend ses marchandises au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée de jeunes et de voisins.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales au niveau de son village et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Mr. Karim S., 24, is single and lives in Hamdallaye, one of the working-class neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Mr. S. tried out several businesses without success. He then decided to get into selling various items in a little shop in front of his house. He has had this little shop (selling cigarettes, bonbons, matches, chewing gum, powdered milk, tea, sugar, soap, etc.) for three years now. He is much in demand by his clientele because of the good quality of his merchandise.

In order to satisfy his ever-growing clientele, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso three months ago, and he is on his first individual loan. With this first loan he intends to buy 2 cartons of cigarettes, 2 cases of tea, 1 sack of sugar, 3 cartons of soap, 5 packs of bonbons, 10 packs of chewing gum, 20 packs of matches, 10 sacks of rice, etc.

He does his buying from wholesalers and sells retail. Mr. S. sells for cash or on credit to a clientele composed of young people and neighbors. With this loan he expects to make a monthly profit of 100,000 F CFA which will be used essentially to increase his working capital, contribute to supporting his family back in the village, and paying the interest on the loan.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Khady

texts.fr: Khady D. est une jeune femme de 30 ans mariée, mère de 3 enfants dont le mari prend la charge. Elle souhaiterait néanmoins ne pas rester inactive. Ce prêt lui servira à acheter des balaies, du jus de citron, de l’huile de palme, du sucre qu’elle va revendre à Ziguinchor et Dakar avec l’aide de son mari qui est transporteur de camions. Elle pense ainsi contribuer à améliorer leurs conditions de vie familiale.
texts.en:
Khady D., 30, is a young married woman and mother of 3 children, whose husband is the breadwinner for the family. She would nevertheless not like to remain inactive. This loan will allow her to buy brooms, lemon juice, palm oil, and sugar which she is going to re-sell in Ziguinchor et Dakar with the help of her husband who does truck transport. She believes that in this way she will be able to contribute to improving family living conditions.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: bolster her business in lemon juice, palm oil, and brooms

loans.name: Karidia

texts.fr:
Née le 10 Août 1975 à Sikasso, Karidia B. est mariée et mère de trois (3) enfants (1 garçon et 2 filles), elle réside avec son époux et leurs enfants à Wayerma II, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Karidia B. est une aide soignante de profession. N’ayant pas eu la chance de pratiquer réellement sa profession, elle n’est pas restée les bras croisés. Alors elle s’est initiée à l’activité d’achat et de vente d’articles divers de boutique(Cigarette, bonbon, allumette, Cheew Gum, lait en poudre, Thé, sucre, etc) devant le domicile conjugal il y a maintenant trois (03) ans. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée par sa clienèle pour la qualité de ses produits.
 Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant trois (3) ans. Après 4 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) correctement remboursés, dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association BENKADI de Wayerma I), elle est à son premier  prêt individuel.
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 4 cartouches de Cigarettes,10 paquets de Cheew Gum, 2 cartons de lait en poudre (en sachets), 10 gros paquets du thé, 1 sac du sucre, 6 alvéoles d’oeufs, 10 paquets de bonbon, 4 cartons de l’eau minerale DIAGO, 20 paquets d’allumette, etc
Elle achète ses marchandises chez les gros commerçants grossistes de place avant de les revendre en détail, au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée de voisins et surtout de jeunes.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour  contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on August 10, 1975 in Sikasso, Karidia B. is married and the mother of 3 children (1 son and 2 daughters) and lives with her husband and children in Wayerma II, one of the working-class neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Mrs. Karidia B. is a professional nurse's aide. Not having had a chance to truly practice her profession, she did not sit back and twiddle her thumbs. She has been selling various items in a little shop (cigarettes, bonbons, matches, chewing gum, powdered milk, tea, sugar, soap, etc.) in front of her family's house for three years now. She is much in demand by her clientele because of the good quality of her merchandise.

In order to satisfy her ever-growing clientele, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After 4 solidarity loans (group loans) correctly reimbursed, together with an association of women from her neighborhood (Association BENKADI of Wayerma I), she is on her first individual loan. With this loan she intends to buy 4 cartons of cigarettes, 10 packs of chewing gum, 2 cartons of powdered milk (in envelopes), 10 big packets of tea, 1 sack of sugar, 6 trays of eggs, 10 packs of bonbons, 20 packs of matches, 4 cartons of mineral water DIAGO brand, etc.

She does her buying from big wholesalers right where she is and sells retail, for cash or on credit, to a clientele composed of neighbors and especially young people. With this loan she expects to make a monthly profit of 100,000 F CFA which will be used essentially to contribute to supporting her family and paying the interest on the loan, investing any remainder back into her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Guillermo Willy

texts.es: El sr. Wily es cliente muy antiguo de la institución  es una persona muy responsable trabajadora. Tiene su restaurant en la avenida principal de la zona, es uno de los mejores restaurants que hay por la zona. Trabaja conjuntamente con su esposa, tiene cuatro niños en edad escolar, viven a unos pasos del negocio, una casita pequeña y acogedora. Atiende todos los días con almuerzo completo  y los fines de semana con platos especiales. El crédito será invertido en la compra de insumos para el restaurant
texts.en:
Wily is an old client of the institution. He is a responsible, hard-working person. He has a restaurant on the main avenue in the district. It is one of the best restaurants that there is in the district. He works with his wife and has four school-aged children. They live a few steps from their business in a small, hospitable home. They serve a complete lunch everyday and special dishes on the weekends. This loan will be invested in buying supplies for the restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies for the restaurant

loans.name: Neema Kimara Group

texts.en:
Eribarik P., age 29, is single. He has a catering business. He started this business in 2006 and works daily from 8am until midnight. He is able to earn a monthly profit of around US$ 177.

This will be Eribarik’s fifth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to build his private house and has repaid the loans successfully. He now hopes for the fifth loan to buy a good stock of food for his business.

Eribarik will share this loan with his loan group "Neema Kimara", which totals 16 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Eribarik is in the middle, front row, in a white T-shirt.

loans.use: To increase his stock of food for food service

loans.name: Dienaba

texts.fr: Dienaba B. est mariée, mère de 4 enfants scolarisés. Elle souhaite avec ce prêt renforcer son activité de vente d’huile et de sucre. Elle s’approvisionne en gros chez un fournisseur de la place qui lui fait la livraison à domicile où elle exerce son commerce. Son objectif est d’améliorer les conditions de vie et de contribuer à la prise en charge sanitaire de sa famille.
texts.en:
Dienaba B. is married and the mother of 4 children, all in school. She would like to use this loan to bolster her little business selling oil and sugar. She buys wholesale from a supplier in town who delivers to her at home, where she has her little business. Her goal is to improve living conditions and support and promote the health of her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: selling oil and sugar out of her home

loans.name: Bintou

texts.fr: Bintou SANE est mariée, mère de 04 enfants scolarisés dont elle a la charge puisque son mari n’est présent au foyer que très rarement. Elle souhaite avec ce prêt réfectionner sa gargote et renforcer son activité de restauration. Elle pourra, de ce fait améliorer les conditions de vie familiale.
texts.en:
Bintou Sané is married and the mother of 4 children, all enrolled in school, for whom she is responsible since her husband is very rarely at home. She wants to use this loan to refurbish her luncheonette and bolster her little food service business. In this way she will be able to improve family living conditions.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: refurbish her luncheonette and stock up on raw materials for her food service

loans.name: Moven Pick Group

texts.en:
Happy H., age 32, is married with two children, ages 5 and 15. She sells clothes. She started this business in 2008. She takes the clothing and sells it upcountry. She is able to earn a monthly profit of about US$ 89.

This will be Happy’s third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the first two to increase her stock by buying more clothes to sell and has paid the loans back successfully. She now hopes for a new loan to open a beauty salon.

Happy will share this loan with subgroup C of the "Maven Pick" group. The subgroup has 7 members who run cafes and salons, sell clothes and vegetables. These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Happy is second from the right.

loans.use: To open a salon

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: La dame Marie G. est une veuve de 50 ans, mère de 04 enfants avec 02 autres tous adultes mais elle continue de participer aux dépenses familiales. Elle envisage avec ce prêt d’acheter de l’huile de palme et du jus de citron pour les revendre en détail. Elle ira s’approvisionner en Guinée Bissau ou la denrée est moins chère pour la revendre à Dakar, la capitale sénégalaise. Le bénéfice obtenu lui permettra d’améliorer ses conditions de vie.
texts.en:
Mrs. Marie G. is a widow, aged 50, the mother of 4 children with two others, all adults, but she continues to participate in covering family expenses. With this loan, she plans to buy palm oil and lemon juice to retail. She will go to stock up in Guinea Bissau where foodstuffs are less expensive, and then will sell her goods in Dakar, the capital of Senegal. The profit she will make will allow her to improve her living conditions.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: bolster her business buying and selling palm oil and lemon juice

loans.name: Socorro

texts.es: Doña Socorro vende prendas de oro laminado que es lo que hoy día se vende más, pues las jóvenes lo usan bastante por su buena calidad y son de costos accesibles, pues la da al contado y al crédito en dos pagos, negocio que lleva seis años, que inicio con prestamos y ha ido creciendo pues compra variedad de prendas, con esta solicitud lo quiere es comprar bastante prendas para ofertar a sus clientes y buscar otros mercado donde pueda vender. La sra. Socorro tiene 48 años de edad, sus hijos están mayores, su esposo no vive ya en casa, pues tiene que esforzarse a vender para subsistir con su familia, pero gracias a Dios tiene el apoyo de sus hijos que le aportan económicamente. Sus planes es poder seguir creciendo en su negocio.
texts.en:
Socorro sells gold-plated jewelry as that is what sells best these days: young people like it because of its good quality and its reasonable price. She sells both for cash and on credit to be repaid in two instalments. She has had this business for six years. She started her business thanks to loans and it has continued to grow. She buys a variety of items. She will use this loan to buy a large amount of jewelry to offer to her customers and to look for new markets in which to sell. Socorro is 48 years old, her children are grown and her husband is not currently living at home. She has to work hard selling in order for her family to survive, but thanks to God she has her children's financial support. She plans to continue growing her business.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a variety of jewelry and expand her business.

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr: Fatoumata C. est une femme mariée, mère de 02 enfants dont elle a la charge. Elle veut ce prêt pour renforcer son commerce de tissus teintés (Thioup), ce qu’elle exerce depuis plusieurs années déjà. Son objectif est d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Fatoumata C. is a married woman, the mother of 2 children for whom she is responsible. She wants this loan to bolster her business selling locally dyed cloth (known as Thiob). She has been in this business for several years already. Her goal is to improve living conditions for her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of locally dyed cloth made using indigo

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en:
Akosua is 51 years old; she is widowed with ten children. Unfortunately two passed away in an accident; two are in school and the rest are fully independent. Her husband died four years ago after a brief illness.

Akosua has been a local manufacturer of palm oil and has sold foodstuffs such as bananas and plantains for the past eight years to take care of her family. Palm oil is produced from palm fruit. The raw palm oil is processed through various stages to obtain the palm oil that is sold. Palm oil is used to prepare many local dishes. Her production is on a small scale due to capital inadequacy to buy machines for the processing.

In addition to her palm oil business, Akosua also sells fruit such as bananas and plantains by the roadside in the community where she lives. She says her business has slowed down due to current food prices and the economic crunch in the world market. She wants to use the loan to buy more palm nuts to increase her capacity to produce oil in larger quantities. She wants the loan for the purchase of bananas and bunches of plantains so that she can supply to her customers on a regular basis.

Akosua belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame Mpa Aba’ which means "God never gives up". She hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: to buy more palm nuts and bananas to restock her inventory

loans.name: Olena

texts.en:
Olena is married with two sons. She owns a business that produces wood products - various souvenirs and decorative items. Her shop is located at home so she does not pay any rent. Her husband and sons are involved in this business too.

Olena has been in this business for more than 10 years. Her husband used to work at a small factory that made similar souvenirs. When the factory downsized, her husband was fired, and they began to produce similar items at home. The produce is sold in bulk in a different city located about 300 miles from them. Recently they bought a van to transport their products.

Olena would like to get a loan of 7,500 UAH to purchase raw materials for production. She hopes to increase the production and use additional profit to fix their house, which burned last summer.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials

loans.name: Afia

texts.en:
Afia B. is 45 years old. She is married with seven children. Three of Afia's children are in school; one has passed away while the rest are independent.

Afia has been a local manufacturer of palm oil and palm kernel oil for twenty years now. Palm oil is produced from palm nuts while palm kernel oil is produced from palm kernels. The palm kernel is a by-product of palm oil. The palm kernel is also processed through various stages to obtain palm kernel oil which is used to prepare many local dishes. She produces both and supplies to food vendors to prepare their meals. She normally switches her production between the two products. That is, after producing palm oil she automatically obtains the raw material to produce palm kernel oil.

She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of palm nuts and an electric milling machine to increase her capacity to produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business to raise more income to help her husband provide support for her family and finance her children's education.

Afia belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame Mpa Aba’ which means "God never gives up". She hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more bags of palm nuts and an electric milling machine

loans.name: Gregoria Bernarda

texts.es: Doña Gregoria tiene 48 años de edad, con dos hijos de 15 y 19 años de edad, que estudian, reside en laureles sur, junto con su esposo trabaja en su negocio que vende mercadería en general en un mercado de la capital de Managua,  desde hace seis años vende, inicio con fondos propios, esta es su quinta solicitud en Afodenic que ha sido de beneficios para invertir en su negocio. Con esta solicitud va a comprar mercadería variada ropa de niño, adultos, chinos de niños, cosméticos   para ofertar  a sus clientes, y la captación de otros, sus objetivos es vender otros productos que generen buenos ingresos a su capital para poder dar estudios a sus hijos y sean unos profesionales.
texts.en:
Gregoria, 48, has two children, 15 and 19, both at school. She lives in the Laureles Sur neighborhood of Managua. With her husband, she's operated a business selling general merchandise in a Managua market for six years. She started the business with her own funds. This is her fifth AFODENIC loan, all of which have been invested in the business. With this loan, Gregoria will buy merchandise, such as clothing and cosmetics, for resale to both her existing customers and any new ones that she can capture. Her goal is to sell different products that will generate the most income so that she, in turn, can educate her children and see them take up professional careers.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing and cosmetics to resell.

loans.name: Alhasan

texts.en:
Alhasan U. is a 35-year-old local restaurant operator. She is married and had four kids; one is married, unfortunately one is deceased, and the other two are still in school. Alhasan lives at Koforidua, a suburb of Kumasi, in the Ashanti region. And she has been there since she started her local restaurant. Alhasan's husband is very supportive in providing the basic needs for the family.

Alhasan prepares and sells local foods like "banku" and other local dishes. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains and it is taken with hot pepper or soup. With her tasty meals she has attracted lots of customers in the area where she serves food. Therefore it has become necessary to employ additional hands to assist her in food service. She has added the sale of bananas to her stock.

Alhasan says prices of raw materials have gone up significantly and she needs the support of a loan to enable her to meet her production expenditure. With the loan, she wants to purchase more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables, firewood, and bunches of bananas to prepare her meals. She would be grateful for your assistance.

Alhasan belongs to a village bank called ‘Nhyira Mma’ which means "Blessed children". She hopes to receive GHS 400 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her to save more to help her husband take care of the Children's educational needs.

loans.use: To buy raw materials like maize, meat, fish, vegetables, firewood, and bunches of bananas

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is forty-nine years old, married, and mother of five children. Currently four of them are in senior high school. She lives with her family in a business centre called Koforidua. Koforidua is a busy market town in the Ashanti Region of Ghana.

Esther says her first-born has completed senior high school. She enjoys selling goods so much that she started working in this business since her youth when she was still living with her parents. She has been selling maize, yams, and traveling bags for over twenty years. She says she buys her goods from the small towns nearby and sells at the local market. At various times, Esther buys beans, groundnuts or other cereals, depending on situation in the villages. She treks to Kumasi to purchase her stock of traveling bags and retails them to customers in the village. She hopes to increase the quantity of foodstuffs that she buys at each trip so as to cut down on her frequent transportation and be able to supply a sizeable market.

Esther belongs to a village bank called ‘Nhyira Mma’ which means "Blessed children". She hopes to receive GHS 1000 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her to save more to help her husband in taking care of the children's educational needs.

loans.use: To buy cereals, yams, and traveling bags for re-sale

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret A., 25, is married with three children. All the kids are currently in school. She is a very resourceful and hard-working mother whose hard effort brings livelihood to the family. Margaret supports her kids through making and selling brooms. Selling brooms has a very big market share in Ghana. Brooms are made from palm branches, by first removing the leaves, leaving the tiny sticks on, and these are gathered to get bunches of brooms for sweeping. She says it is economically good to do that business and has been selling brooms for the past three years. She travels to nearby villages to buy the palm branches and prepares them for retail. She wants to use the loan to buy more palm branches to increase her inventory. She believes this loan would help her save for her children's future and also to rent a store to sell out of. 

Margaret belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame yekese’ which means "God is bigger". She hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her to save more to help her husband in taking care of the children's educational needs.

loans.use: To buy increased numbers of palm branches for preparation of brooms

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana is divorced and has one daughter who is 7 years old. She owns a retail business that sells office supplies. Her business has got a very good downtown location, which brings many customers her way. 

Svetlana has been in this business for seven years already. Her father gave Svetlana this business idea. She began to work and was quite successful.

Svetlana would like to get a loan of 5,000 UAH to increase her assortment. Her financial goal is to purchase a car. Svetlana is a lively and hard-working person and believes she can make enough money to reach her goal.

loans.use: to increase her assortment

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia A. is married with four children. Currently, all her children who haven't completed high school are in school. She lives with her husband and their kids at Koforidua in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She works very hard because the partial responsibility for the kids rests on her shoulders as a mother. She is now 45 years old.

Lydia sells home products such as cooking utensils, plastic bowls, buckets and plates. She makes her sales by ‘hawking’, which is door-to-door sales. Lydia is an achiever and her focus is to save enough to send her kids through school. She wants to use the loan to buy increased stocks of plastic goods and kitchen sets to serve her customers. She would be very grateful your support.

Lydia belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame Akwan’ which means "God’s way". She hopes to receive GHS 400 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her to save more to help her husband in taking care of the children's educational needs.

loans.use: To buy increased stock of plastic goods and kitchen sets

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.es:
Rosa Maria C. tiene una miscelánea que se llama “Estanquillo Rosa” con esta tiendita  ya tiene 18 años. La señora Rosa vende de todo fritos, refrescos, chicharrones con repollo, abarrotes y en temporadas de calor “nieve”. Ahora ella no ha podido surtir su negocio por que comenta que en estos meses son bajas las ventas, pero llegando el verano vende más que ahora.
 Ella quiere abastecer su estanquillo para tener más fuentes de dinero, aunque su esposo es una ayuda para ella ya que  trabaja como chofer de camión, tiene dos hijos los cuales todavía están en escuela  y quiere que tengan mejor educación.
texts.en:
Rosa Maria C. has a corner shop that is called “Estanquillo Rosa” ["Rosa's General Store"]. She has owned this little store for 18 years. Rosa sells fried foods, soft drinks, fried pork with cabbage, provisions, and, in hot seasons "nieve" ["snow"]. Currently, she has been unable to supply her business because sales have decreased in these months, but now that summer is coming she is selling more than before. Rosa wants to stock her general store so that she will have more sources of income, even though her husband is a help to her given that he works as a truck driver. She has two children who are still in school and she wants them to have a better education.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise for her store

loans.name: Kwami

texts.fr:
Monsieur K. kwami habite le quartier d’agoè sagnako, un quartier au nord de la ville de lomé, il fait comme activité l’elavage des poules, la vente e poulets et des œufs, il vend aux restaurants et bar de son quartier, il fait lui-même aussi la cuisson sur commande, il a commencé ce commerce en 2004. Il s’approvisionne dans des fermes du ghana parce que là bas c’est moins chèr. La demande étant un peu élevé ces temps ci, il soliicite un crédit de 450000F pour pouvoir acheter 400 poules pour pouvoir satisfaire ses clients.
Ce monsieur est marié et mère de 03 enfants.
texts.en:
Mr. Kwami K. lives in the Agoè Sagnako neighborhood, a district north of the town of Lomé. His business is raising poultry and selling chickens and eggs. He sells to the restaurants and bars in his district. He even cooks to order. He began this business in 2004.

Kwami buys his poultry at the farms in Ghana because it is less expensive there. Since demand has somewhat increased recently, he is requesting a loan of 450,000 F to be able to buy 400 hens to satisfy the needs of his clientele. This gentleman is married and the father of 3 children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of hens for re-sale

loans.name: Aminatou

texts.fr: I. aminatou  est une dame qui vit dans le quartier de togblékopé,  elle fait comme activité la vente de produits génériques, elle est divorcée et mère de deux (02) enfants, son travail lui permet de pouvoir subvenir convenablement aux charges de ses deux enfants. Elle voudrait agrandir son stock  pour avoir un  surplus de revenu et mieux entretenir sa famille. Elle n’a jamais obtenu de prêt et sollicite ce premier crédit de 300000 de wages pour acheter 10 boîtes de palidar, 20 boites de tanzol, 10 boîtes de cirotamin et 28 boîtes de detonic.
texts.en:
Aminatou I. is a woman who lives in the Togblékopé district. Her business involves selling generic pharmaceutical products. She is divorced and the mother of two. Her work enables her to care for her two children appropriately. She would like to expand her inventory to earn more income and to provide for her family better. Never having been a recipient of a loan, she is requesting this initial loan of 300,000 francs from WAGES, a Kiva partner. The loan will be used to buy: 10 containers of palidar, 20 containers of tanzol, 10 containers of cirotamin, and 28 containers of detonic.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy generic pharmceuticals

loans.name: Ablavi

texts.fr: Madame MLAGANI ablavi habite le quartrier d’agoè à lomé, elle a pour activtés génératrices de revenus la vente de chaussures et de produits génériques, elle a commencé à faire ce travail au debut de l’année 2008, elle est mariée et  a eu deux (02) enfants avec son mari qui est employé à la lonato. Avec ce qu’elle gagne de plus de ce commerce, elle arrive à aider son mari dans les dépenses du foyer. Etant en besoin de réapprovisionnement, elle sollicite de chez wages un crédit d’un montant de 150000F CFA
texts.en:
Ms. Ablavi MLAGANI lives in the Agoè district in Lomé. She works to earn an income selling shoes and generic pharmaceutical products. This is work that she began in the beginning of 2008. She is married and has two children with her husband, who is employed at LONATO (the national lottery of Togo). With what she earns in addition to her commerce, she manages to assist her husband in covering household expenses. Being in need of supplies, she is requesting from WAGES a loan in the amount of 150,000 francs CFA.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy shoes and generic pharmceuticals for resale

loans.name: Alfonso

texts.es: A sus 59 años, Alfonso es conciente que para progresar en la vida tiene que trabajar arduamente, vive en un cuarto alquilado junto a su esposa, y juntos quieren salir adelante. Habiendo vivido su niñez en su natal Amantani (Isla del lago Titicaca), Alfonso sabe que muchas veces escasean los productos en su isla. Son ya 10 años que tiene en el negocio de la venta de productos agrícolas, él surca las aguas del lago Titicaca todas las semanas llevando sus productos y no solo se limita a transportar lo que él cosecha, sino también abastece a su isla de todo lo que sus moradores podrían necesitar (Víveres, muebles, abarrotes, etc), su negocio es muy rentable, ya que es el único que realiza esta labor.  Alfonso es feliz sabiendo que a los pobladores de Amantani, no les falta nada gracias a su esfuerzo, pero justamente trasladar todo sus productos, es lo más difícil de su trabajo, él quiere darle una mejor vida a su esposa, que es quien más le ayuda en su trabajo, es por eso que nunca descansa en el afán de cumplir sus metas. Este primer préstamo le ayudará a Alfonso a progresar, quiere cumplir con todas sus cuotas y de esta manera no poner en dificultades, a su banco comunal. Con el dinero que solicita planea comprar más mercadería para llevar a su isla, invertirá todo el préstamo en ello, ya que siente que los moradores de Amantani todavía necesitan muchas cosas.
texts.en:
At 59 years of age, Alfonso is aware that he has to work hard to progress in life. He lives in a rented room with his wife, and both of them want to move forward. Having spent his childhood on his native Amantani Island (Lake Titicaca), Alfonso knows that produce there is frequently in short supply. He has been in the business of selling farm produce for 10 years now and sails across Titicaca every week with his goods. He not only takes over the produce he has harvested, but also stocks the inhabitants of the island with everything they might need (supplies, furniture, groceries, etc.). His is a very profitable trade, as he is the only person doing this job. It makes Alfonso happy to know that the people of Amantani want for nothing thanks to his efforts, but transporting all of these goods is the hardest aspect of his work. He wants to give his wife a better life, she being the person who helps him the most in his labours, hence his unwaivering determination to achieve his goals. This first loan will help Alfonso to move forward. He wants to keep up with his payments so as to avoid creating difficulties for his local communal bank. He intends to use the requested money - indeed, the entire loan - to buy more merchandise to take to the island, as he feels that the residents of Amantani still need a good many things.

Translated from Spanish by Eleanor Stilgoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Ceferina

texts.es: Ceferina, es una madre abnegada, que desea con todas sus fuerzas ver profesional a su único hijo, a sus 54 años a logrado tener su casa propia, pero aun quiere obtener muchas cosas más. Para Ceferina, su hijo Cristian de 11 años, se ha convertido en el principal motivo de todos sus esfuerzos. Con su bolsa de cosméticos en mano, sale todos los días a convencer a sus clientas de comprarle una crema o alguna pieza de maquillaje, Ceferina es muy convincente en su trabajo, no en vano es una de las mejores vendedoras y lleva ya 3 años en este negocio, del cual lo que más le gusta, es conversar con sus clientes e informarle sobre los productos más novedosos, en el futuro le gustaría poner su tienda de cosméticos, puesto que se le hace muy difícil cobrarle a sus clientes todos los meses. Ella trabaja sin descanso mes a mes con el único fin de mejorar la vida que actualmente lleva su adorado hijo Cristian. MFP le a concedido por primera vez un préstamo a Ceferina, quien esta muy feliz por ello, ha trabajado mucho en su banco comunal para lograr este crédito y no quiere faltar a ninguna de sus cuotas. Con este préstamo, Ceferina comprará más cosméticos, invertirá todo el monto en incrementar su mercadería, para tener productos más surtidos.
texts.en:
Ceferina is a selfless mother who wants, with all her might, to see her only son adopt a profession. At 54, she's managed to get her own house but there are still a lot of things she wants. For Ceferina, her son, Cristian, 11, has become the focus of all her efforts. With her bag of cosmetics in hand, she goes out every day to convince her customers to buy a cream or some item of make-up from her. Ceferina is very persuasive and it's not surprising that she's one of the top saleswomen. She's operated the business for 3 years. What she likes most is talking to customers and telling them about new products. In the future, she would like to set up her own cosmetics shop becuase she's found it difficult to see all of her customers during every month. Ceferina works tirelessly, month after month, with the single-minded goal of making a better life for her beloved son, Cristian. This is Ceferina's first MFP loan and she's very happy to get it. She's worked hard at her community bank to get this loan and doesn't want to miss a single installment. She will use the loan to buy more cosmetics, investing the total amount in adding merchandise so that she has the stock she needs.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Add merchandise.

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es: Graciela de 26 años, tiene una casa propia, donde vive con su esposo y su hija Leydi de tan solo 5 añitos, quiere mejorar su futuro y el de su familia y para eso trabaja arduamente. De manera ambulatoria, Graciela sale todos los días a vender las chuspitas artesanales que teje, las vende en el distrito de Ilave a una hora de la ciudad de Puno, lleva ya 10 años en este negocio, el cual le a traído muchas satisfacciones, ella es una tejedora nata, disfruta mucho de su trabajo, prácticamente teje a cada hora del día, pero le resulta muy difícil trasladar toda su mercadería, desde Puno a Ilave y es justamente este sacrificio lo que hace que venda más, ya que no tiene mucha competencia, Graciela está dispuesta a trabajar mucho, con el fin de darle a su querida hija unos buenos estudios y no hacerle faltar nada, ya que ella sabe lo que es no tener las comodidades necesarias. Este primer préstamo le ayudará mucho a Graciela, para mejorar su negocio y es conciente de que tiene que pagar todas sus cuotas, para no perjudicar a su banco comunal. Graciela desea comprar más lana, para hacer sus artesanías, esto le costará alrededor de 300 nuevos soles, con el resto del dinero planea comprar artesanías a otras tejedoras para venderlas en Ilave.
texts.en:
Graciela, 26, owns her own house. She lives there with her husband and her daughter, Leydi, 5. She wants a better future for herself and her family and she's working hard to get it. Graciela works as a street vendor, going out every day to sell home-made "chuspitas" (a knitted or woven bag or purse). She sells them in the "distrito" of Ilave, an hour from the city of Puno. She's operated the business for 10 years and it's given her a lot of satisfaction. She knits like she was born to do it and she enjoys her work. She practically spends every hour of the day knitting, so much that it's become difficult for her to carry all her merchandise from Puno to Ilave. She makes the sacrifice, though, because there's not much competition there and she can sell more. Graciela is happy to work hard because it will allow her to give her darling daughter a good education. Graciela knows what it's like to not have everyday necessities and she wants to make sure her daughter has the things she needs. This first loan will help Graciela improve her business and she's well aware that she has to pay all her installments in order not to prejudice her community bank. Graciela wants to buy more wool to make her crafts. That will cost around 300 new soles. With the rest of the money, she plans to buy crafts from other artisans so that can sell them in Ilave.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wool to make crafts for sale.

loans.name: Juana

texts.es: A sus 43 años, Juana quiere seguir progresando, vive en su casa propia, junto a su pequeña hija Yamile, de solo 12 años, quien es el motivo de todos sus esfuerzos. Juana es una madre ejemplar, que disfruta de vender ropa y peluches en su pequeño puesto en la ciudad de Puno, es feliz ayudando y apoyando a sus vecinas vendedoras en mejorar su negocio, sabe que necesita mucha ayuda para mejorar su futuro y le es muy difícil conseguir los peluches que vende, pues los que ella vende son diferente y muy especiales. Tiene ya 4 años vistiendo a sus clientes, quiere en el futuro hacer crecer su puesto y que se convierta en uno de los más conocidos, su deseo es que su hija Yamile tenga las oportunidades que ella nunca tuvo y para ello trabaja sin descanso en espera de cumplir sus metas. Este es su segundo préstamo en MFP, Juana es la socia más puntual en sus cuotas, es por eso  que su banco comunal le tiene mucha confianza. Ahora planea invertir en un nuevo negocio, quiere poner un puesto de comida, ella se siente capaz de realizar ambos trabajos y no le disgusta la idea de trabajar más, con tal de mejorar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Fourty-three years of age, Juana wants to continue to make progress. She lives in a house she owns with her young 12-year-old daughter Yamile who is the reason behind all her efforts. Juana is an exemplary mother who enjoys selling clothing and plush toys from her small store in the city of Puno. She is happy helping and supporting her neighbouring merchants in improving her business. She knows that it takes alot of help to make a better future and it is very difficult for her to get the plush toys she sells as hers are different and very special. She has been taking care of her customers for four years already and wants to expand her location in the future and that she can become one of the most renowned merchants. She hopes that her daughter Yamile will have opportunities which she never had and for her she works without rest hoping to accomplish her goals. This is her second loan with MFP; Juana is the most punctual member in her repayments and because of this her community bank has a great deal of confidence in her. She is now planning to invest in a new business: she wants to begin selling food and feels that she is capable of doing both jobs and does not mind the idea of working more as long as she improves her income.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment capital to open a new business.

loans.name: Juana

texts.es: Juana ha pasado la mayor parte de su vida tratando de salir adelante, vive en su casa propia y a sus 50 años lucha por darle a sus 3 hijos; Alexander, Jakeline y Flor la vida que se merecen. Con la ayuda de ellos emprende su negocio diario, ella vende ropa en su propia casa y disfruta de conversar con sus clientes, lo más difícil es conseguir la ropa que vende, puesto que tiene que adquirir lo más bonito y elegante, su negocio es muy rentable, ya que no solo vende ropa a sus clientes, sino que también le vende a pequeños puestos de ropa, los cuales compran las prendas directamente de la casa de Juana. La experiencia de 8 años que tiene haciendo este negocio, le ha dado el conocimiento necesario para hacerlo crecer, quiere tener una tienda en un lugar céntrico, para vender más y mejorar sus ingresos económicos. Juana se encuentra en su segundo préstamo con MFP y sabe que tiene que poner todo de su parte para pagar sus cuotas, además es la secretaria de su banco comunal y tiene que dar el ejemplo. Con este nuevo préstamo, quiere incrementar su mercadería, comprar más zapatos, blusas, jeans, etc., e invertirá todo el dinero del crédito en ello.
texts.en:
Juana has spent a large part of her life trying to improve her economic situation. She lives in her own house and she is 50 years old. She has worked hard to give her 3 children, Alexander, Jakeline and Flor, the life that they deserve. Her children now help her with her business. She sell clothes out of her home and she enjoys talking to her customers. The hardest part of her business is getting the clothing to sell, since she needs to get the prettiest and most elegant clothing. Her business is very profitable. She also sells clothing to small stores and stands. These stores buy the items directly from Juana's house. Juana has 8 years of experience in the business and it has given her the knowledge that she needs to make the business grow. She wants to open her own store in a central location. She wants to sell more and to increase her income. This will be Juana's second loan through MFP and she knows that she will have to work hard so that she can make all of the payments. She is also the secretary and her communal bank and she has to be a example for everyone. She will invest the money for the loan in the purchase of new merchandise, like shoes, blouses, jeans, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Kendra Gaete, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase Her Merchandise

loans.name: Lupe

texts.es: Lupe de 43 años, vive con su esposo Sebastián que es albañil y sus 3 menores hijos; Ángel de 14, Cristian de 10 y la tierna Paola de 6 años, en una cuarto alquilado, ella quiere mejorar su futuro y quiere lograrlo haciendo crecer su negocio. Se dedica a llevar y vender ropa a las comunidades más alejadas de Puno, montada en un camión transporta toda su mercadería, esto es lo más difícil de su trabajo, pero cuando llega a su destino, se distrae mucho vendiendo la ropa, la cual se acaba rápidamente. Tiene 10 años haciendo esta actividad, desea establecerse y poner una tienda de ropa. A pesar de sus constantes viajes, trata de no descuidar a sus hijos, a los que ama un montón y siempre que puede esta con ellos, lo que más anhela es darles unos estudios adecuados, para que luego sean unos buenos y competentes profesionales. Es el primer préstamo de Lupe con MFP y ya está ahorrando para pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo, su banco comunal la apoya puesto que es una de las más entusiastas del grupo. Lupe quiere comprar más mercadería, ya que quiere hacer crecer su negocio, así que invertirá todo el préstamo en la compra de ropa.
texts.en:
Lupe is 43 years old. She lives with her husband who is a bricklayer and her three young children, Angel, 14, Cristian 10, and Paola, 6. The live in a rented room. Se wants to improve her future by making her business grow. She makes a living by selling clothing in far away and remote communities outside of Puno. The worst part of her job is riding on the back of a truck with all of her merchandise to get to the locations where she sells the clothes. However, as soon as she arrives the time passes by quickly as she sells the clothing. She always sells out of her merchandise quickly. She has been making a living this way for the past 10 years. She would like to start a clothing store someday.

Despite her constant traveling, she doesn't leave her children unattended. She loves them very much and she is with them whenever possible. Her greatest dream is to give them a proper education so that the can become good and competent professionals. This is Lupe's first loan through MFP and she already started saving so that she will be able to make all her payments on time. Her communal bank helps her a lot and she is one of its most enthusiastic members. Lupe wants to buy merchandise. She wants her business to grow and that is why she will invest the loan in the purchase of clothing.

(Translated by Jian of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by Kendra Gaete, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase Her Merchandise

loans.name: Ramón Ruben

texts.es:
El señor Ramón Pérez se desempeña en su negocio de venta de frutas y verduras en el mercado central de la ciudad de Chinandega donde se ha destacado por ser un excelente comerciante que a diario desde muy tempranas horas atiende en su establecimiento.

Es de importancia destacar que el señor Ramón se esfuerza diariamente en su negocio, trasladando los perecederos hasta el mercado con el propósito de venderlos. La razón por la que el señor Pérez busca el apoyo en Ceprodel es para obtener un crédito que le permita la compra de dichos perecederos para su respectiva venta y así mejorar sus condiciones económicas.
texts.en:
Ramón Pérez takes pride in his business selling fruit and vegetables. He runs a stand in the central market in the city of Chinadega. He is a dedicated merchant, working daily beginning in the early morning.

It is important to highlight that Ramón works diligently every day, transporting his produce to the market to sell. Ramón is hoping for a loan so that he can continue to buy his produce, maintaining his business and improving his economic condition.

(Translated by Ally of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by Kendra Gaete, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase Fruit and Vegetables

loans.name: Marlene

texts.es:
La señora Marlene D. se dedica a su negocio de venta de verduras y frutas en su propio tramo en el mercado central de la ciudad de Chinandega donde se dedica arduamente a laborar.

Sus ventas las realiza desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana atendiendo muy amablemente y cada vez que se lleva a cabo una venta, ella entrega el producto en bolsas y con una alegre sonrisa ya que es una dama muy sonriente. Su necesidad es la adquisición de las frutas y verduras por lo que ya se le han estado agotando y es por esto que espera en Ceprodel para obtener un crédito y de esta forma continuar en su negocio que tanto requiere de su apoyo.
texts.en:
Marlene D. works extremely hard selling fruit and vegetables in her own section of the central market in the city of Chinandega. She begins work very early in the morning but always serves her customers in a friendly way. Everytime she completes a sale, she bags the purchase with a happy smile, as she is a person who is always smiling. She needs to purchase more fruits and vegatables to replace those which have sold out. For this reason she has requested a loan from Kiva partner Ceprodel, which will allow her to continue her business as it requires a lot of her support.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Martyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing vegetables

loans.name: Sandra Mercedes

texts.es:
Sandra L. es una dama que se ha caracterizado por ser una muy buena comerciante de venta de ropa y mochilas de todo tipo atendiendo en su tramo en el Mercado central de la ciudad de Chinandega.

El negocio ha venido desarrollándose satisfactoriamente gracias a sus esfuerzos múltiples. Hoy en dia ha buscado el apoyo en Ceprodel para la compra de las mochilas debido a que es inicio de año y por esto las ventas se incrementan por iniciar las clases escolares y es importante tener bastante mercadería para ofrecer y de esta forma satisfacer la necesidad de los clientes.
texts.en:
Sandra L. is a woman known for being a very good shopkeeper who sells clothing and backpacks of all types in her section of the Central Market in the city of Chinandega. Her business has been developing in a satisfactory way thanks to her many efforts. She is now looking for support from Kiva partner Ceprodel in order to purchase backpacks. As it is the beginning of the year her sales will increase because school classes are starting, and it is important to have enough merchandise to offer in order to satisfy her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Martyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing backpacks

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en:
Mrs. Chantha V. is a farmer in Angk Prasat village in Takeo province. She owns a small piece of land where she cultivates rice. Aside from this plantation, she is a rice middleman. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more rice to re-sell to earn more profit. Her husband, Mr. Thou Sophal, is a laborer.

Mrs. Chantha V. is 40 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are enrolled in the local school while the other is too young to work or study. Her husband is also in the photo.

loans.use: to buy more rice to keep in stock and re-sell at a better price

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en:
Felisa R. is engaged in selling goods. She sells rice, canned goods, beverages, soaps, and other products for a living. She is now 42 years old. She is still single and lives with her parents. She wants to have a bigger store someday and CEVI, according to her, will help her achieve her dreams. She started her store in 2005. With the small amount of Php 4,000, she managed to put up a small store in front of their house. The profit that she gets from selling various kinds of products is what she uses to pay their daily expenses.

She is asking for a CEVI loan of Php 4,000. She will use the loan to buy more products to sell. Part of the loan also is for her business expansion. She is also interested to look for some other income opportunities to support her needs and her parents'.

CEVI helps Felisa grow her business. Now, she enjoys having credit assistance, training about running a business, and insurance coverage from CEVI.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her store

loans.name: Hen

texts.en:
Mrs. Hen L. lives in Chhoer Teal Phlos village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Keo Poy, helps her with her plantation. In this plantation, they face some problems because they do not have enough money to purchase rice seed, pesticides, fertilizer, and to hire laborers to work on their field.

In order to solve these problems, Mrs. Hen L. decided to ask for a loan for those purposes. She is 54 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is a tailor while the others are attending the local school. Her husband is also in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase rice seed, pesticides, fertilizer, and to hire laborers to work on their field

loans.name: Flaviano

texts.en:
Flaviano G. is a "nipa" maker, that is, a woven roof which is composed of a very light material from the "nipa" plant. "Nipa" in the Philippines is used to roof houses; it is an an aquatic plant and is popular in the country. Flaviano has 3 children, 2 boys and a girl. He was previously working as a carpenter. Now, he focuses more on his business, which is nipa-roof manufacturing.

He is requesting a loan from CEVI. He will use the loan to buy more nipa materials for making roofs. He is also willing to do another line of business to augment their family income.

"I am thankful because I am part of CEVI's program. Now, I have easy access to their credit assistance and training services. I am also covered by their insurance package since I joined CEVI," he said.

loans.use: To buy more nipa (plant) materials to prepare for roofing

loans.name: Chanda

texts.en: Mrs. Chanda S. is a farmer in Trapaing Kok village in Takeo province. She owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Nouch Sothea, is a construction worker. Even though they try to work hard, they still earn very little income to support their household. In order to improve their living standards, Mrs. Chanda S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She has three children, two of whom are enrolled in the local school while the other is too young to work or study. Her husband is also in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Mr. Sorn L., 51, and his wife, Mrs. Yat Cheng, 48, who live in a small village in the suburbs of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia, married in 1980 and have four children: one son and three daughters. One of their daughters is a tailor; another one has full-time employment, and two children are in school.

Sorn has been a driving a motor taxi for one year. He does his job in Phnom Penh and earns about US$ 2.50 a day. His wife has been a tailor for seven years and earns about US$ 3.75 per day.

Sorn is requesting his first a loan of US$ 600 to purchase a motorbike for his children to ride to school. Part of the loan will be used to buy a sewing machine for his daughter’s business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for his children to drive to school and buy a sewing machine for his daughter’s business.

loans.name: Sok-Heang

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok-heang, 49, and her husband, Mrs. Porn Khut, 54, married in 1981 and have nine children: four sons and five daughters. Three of their children are married and live outside the family home. Their eldest son is a construction worker and the other children attend school. The family lives on an island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sok-heang and her husband have been farming since 1975. They grow rice, tomatoes and sweet potatoes in their farmland not too far from the village and sell their produce to a middleman in the village. Sok-heang is requesting her first loan of US$ 200 to purchase diesel for their water pump and fertilizer for growing rice.

loans.use: To purchase diesel and fertilizer for growing rice

loans.name: Socheat

texts.en:
Mr. Socheat T., 28 and his wife, Mrs. Sreymom Boeun, 19, married in 2006 and just have one young daughter. The family lives along National Road Number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Socheat has been a blacksmith for seven years and started his own business five months ago. Before he started his own shop, he was employed in a shop near his village. His wife stays at home to take care of their daughter. Socheat lacks money to expand his business so he is requesting his first loan of US$ 1000 to purchase blacksmith's materials for his new shop.

loans.use: To purchase blacksmith's materials for his business

loans.name: Yoin

texts.en:
Miss Yoin K. (pictured with her mother), 37, is single and lives with her parents in a small village along National Road Number Five about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. She has five brothers and two sisters. Three of her brothers are married and live outside the family home; two sisters are garment factory workers and another one is a farmer.

Yoin has been a garment factory worker for six years; the main income in the family comes from her and her brothers' and sisters' salaries and from the farming business. Her mother also raises pigs at home. Yoin is requesting her second loan of US$ 1000 to purchase a boat motor, to buy piglets for raising, and to use for growing rice.

loans.use: To purchase a boat motor, to buy piglets for raising, and to use for growing rice

loans.name: Vongsarith

texts.en:
Mr. Vongsarith V., 49, and his wife, Mrs. Iyani Choeng, 46, married in 1986 and have five children: two sons and three daughters. One of their children is married and lives outside the family home; two children attend school; one child is a garment factory worker and another one is still young. The family lives in a small village off of National Road Number Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh.

Vongsarith has been a mason since 1990. His wife was a cleaner in a hotel in Phnom Penh for six years. He is requesting his first loan of US$ 200 to add to his own money to buy a new motorbike to replace his old one to drive to work.

loans.use: To add to his own money to buy a new motorbike to replace his old one to drive to work

loans.name: Seangbunq

texts.en:
Mr. Seangbunq N., 40, and his wife, Mrs. Sokvet Theab, 28, married in 1998 and have two children: one young son and one daughter attending school. The family lives in a small village off of National Road Number Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh.

Seangbunq has been driving a motor taxi in Phnom Penh for four years. His wife has been a garment factory worker for nine years. Seangbunq’s motorbike is old and breaks down often and he plans to exchange it for a new one. That's why he is requesting his first loan of US$ 300 to add to his own money to buy a new motorbike to replace his old one for driving as a motor taxi.

loans.use: To replace his old motorbike for his motor taxi business

loans.name: Varet

texts.en:
Mrs. Varet D., 28, and her husband, Mr. Chhounvy Khim, 36, were married in 2003 and have one daughter. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Varet has been a silk weaver since she was sixteen years old, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell at the market in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a mechanic and mason since he got married. She is requesting a loan of US$ 400 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Buntheng

texts.en:
