Mr. Buntheng V., 30, and his wife, Mrs. Sreymao Pol, 33, who live in a small village across the Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia, married in 1996 and have three children: one son and two daughters. Two of their children attend school and another one is still too young.

Buntheng and his wife have been selling fish for thirteen years. They buy them from the market in Phnom Penh for re-sale in the village market. Now, the couple is in the process of running their new business: selling rice and dried salted fish.

Therefore, Buntheng is requesting his first loan of US$ 1,000 to purchase rice and fish to make dried salted fish for re-sale.

loans.use: To purchase rice for re-sale and fish to make dried salted fish for re-sale

loans.name: Chhouem

texts.en:
Chhouem H. was born in 1950 and he currently lives in the Siem Reap Province of Cambodia. He is married to Mrs. Morm, who is 46 years old; his wife generates income by raising pigs in a stall next to their house. The couple has two children (one is married while the other is single), both of whom are employed.

To earn a living, he grows vegetables, but he also owns and operates a rice mill machine out of his house (i.e., he provides a rice-hulling service). H. is seeking a loan for the benefit of his wife's business; specifically, she would use the capital infusion to buy more food for her pigs in order to fatten them.

loans.use: To fatten pigs by purchasing additional pig food

loans.name: Leangheng

texts.en:
Mrs. Leangheng P. is 37 years old, and her husband, Mr. Da Dorn, is 34 years old. They live in a small village across the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They married in 1994, and they have two children (one son and one daughter), both of whom are in school.

Leangheng has been selling grocery items for six years. She buys her groceries from the markets in Phnom Penh and subsequently resells them in her village. Her husband, meanwhile, has been a mechanic for over ten years. He works in Phnom Penh during the day and back home at night.

Leangheng hopes to be able to pay for her children’s future educational endeavors. As such, she is requesting her first loan in the amount of $1,000 to build a kitchen and bathroom for the benefit of her family and to expand her business by purchasing more groceries for resale.

loans.use: To improve her family's home by building a kitchen and bathroom and to expand her business by purchasing additional groceries

loans.name: Lai

texts.en:
Mrs. Lai K. is 57 years old, and her husband, Mr. Toun Kong, is 60 years old. They live along national road number one, approximately 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They married in 1973, and they have eight children (five sons and three daughters). Three of their children are married and do not live in their famiy's home; in addition, they note that one of their sons is a Police of Military, another son is a full-time employee at an NGO, while the other children are in school.

Lai and her husband have been selling fruit for five years. More specifically, they buy fruit from the Chroy Ampil commune, which is approximately 12 kilometers from her village, and they resell such fruit at markets in Phnom Penh. Lai is now requesting her first loan in the amount of $1,100 to purchase additional fruit as well as clothing for resale purposes.

loans.use: To purchase additional fruit and clothing for resale

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mrs. Mao C., 40, and her husband, Mr. Chea Pen, 40, live along National Road Number One, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1985 and have six sons. One of their sons is a security guard; two sons are fishermen, and the other three are in school.

Mao and her husband have been fishing for ten years. They catch fish in the lake at the back of their house and sell them at the Koki market. Mao is requesting her first loan of $700. She will use part of the loan to purchase fishing materials and part of it she will add to her own money to buy a plot of land to build their house.

loans.use: To purchase fishing materials and to buy a plot of land

loans.name: Soklin

texts.en:
Mrs. Soklin L., 41, and her husband, Mr. Teat Ly, 42, were married in 1991 and have three children: two sons and one daughter, all of whom attend school. The family lives along National Road Number Qne, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia.

Soklin has been a scarf weaver since she was 18 years old, a skill she learned from her parents. She sells her finished products at a market in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a policeman since 1987. Soklin is asking for a loan of $500 to purchase cotton thread materials for her scarf weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase cotton thread materials for her scarf weaving business

loans.name: Battogtoh

texts.en: Ms. Battogtoh B. is a 39-year-old widowed mother of two sons. In 2007, she started operating a food stall selling vegetables, bread, milk, and other foods to make money to feed her sons. In June 2008, she expanded her business by opening a general store in the yard in front of her house. She also receives 54,000 MNT (about $35-40 USD) a month from the government as a pension for her husband's death. Battogtoh lives in a traditional Mongolian ger about 130 km from Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. She and her sons built the new store themselves. Both of her sons -- aged 12 and 16 -- go to school and help run the family business.  When Battogtoh goes to the market to buy goods, her eldest son works at the store and her youngest son goes with her to help carry the goods. The average daily income in the store is 30,000-50,000 MNT (about $20-40 USD), which mostly comes from selling milk, cigarettes, and bread. Most of the store's customers are Battogtoh's neighbors. This 400,000 MNT loan is the second loan she has taken from XacBank, Kiva's Mongolian microfinance partner. Battogtoh is a very open and active person. She now plans to renovate the structure housing her store.

loans.use: To buy new and varied inventory for her general store

loans.name: Neema J.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 33-year-old Neema H. from Mbeya. She is married and has one child who is 12 years old. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependant because he is an orphan. 

Neema has been running a grocery and crops business since 2006. She buys different types of crops from the farmers and sells them in town. She works at the business for 16 hours a day, 5 days a week and is assisted by one employee. Neema currently earns about $100 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $600 USD to purchase maize, beans, and rice in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the variety of crops she sells. Neema thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Women are considered non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This situation leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase maize, beans, and rice in bulk.

loans.name: Eva J.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 28-year-old Eva L. from Mbeya. She is married and has an 8-year-old child. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two other dependants because they are orphans—their parents died of HIV. 

Eva has been running a salon since 2005. Hair, hair, and more hair! This is the place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, or blue hair, and then have it attached to your head, woven, cut, or plaited, and made to look like your own.

She works at the business for 9-12 hours a day, 7 days a week. Eva currently earns about $100 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $450 USD to purchase more hair products and cosmetics. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and the range of her business. Eva thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Women are considered non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This situation leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase hair products and cosmetics

loans.name: Nabi

texts.en:
A. Nabi is 67 years old. He is married and the father of 3 children. Nabi is a hard-working man who has struggled to provide for his family and educate his children, who are today, working adults thanks to his example. Nabi is an enterprising man who constantly tries to make things better and to improve every day. He works hard in his fields and spends as much time as possible providing the necessary care, fertilizing the land and spraying to prevent diseases that might affect his yields. Nabi needs tools and fertilizers to continue his difficult work of tending his crops, so that they can be taken to the capital for sale. He is applying for a loan of $ 500 USD. Let's be the ones who reach out our hands to help Nabi.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase mineral fertilizer, fuels and lubricants.

loans.name: Musurmonkul

texts.en:
Musurmonkul A. works in agriculture. For this, he leaves his home to head for his distant farmlands that he must care for and fertilize at certain times. He has been farming for the past 7 years. He learned all the secrets and experiences of farming from his father. He tells us that, beyond the hard work, he does everything for the good of his family.

Musurmonkul is asking for a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizer, fuel and lubricants with the goal that, in the coming harvest, he will have good quality, profitable products. Musurmonkul hopes that you can meet his request for the good of his agricultural production.

loans.use: Purchasing seeds, fertilizer, fuel and lubricants

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha M. owns a neighborhood store. She sells a variety of goods that brighten her customer's lives and provide them with something good to eat. “I am dreaming of having a grocery store business someday," she said. “I want to do my very best to help my family and send my children to school." she added.

Her business is located next to her house near the San Jose elementary school. She is lucky to have the school so close to her store, because the students provide Editha with regular business and income. Editha is asking for a CEVI loan of 21,000 PHP to purchase meat, vegetables, and various goods for her store.

CEVI helps entrepreneurs like Editha to grow their businesses. CEVI provides credit assistance, training, and insurance services to their clients.

loans.use: Purchase meat, vegetables, and goods to sell

loans.name: Alikul

texts.en:
Alikul M. is married and the father of five children. He works as a farmer every day. Educated up to secondary school, he had to quit early because he couldn't afford to attend high school. Alikul, with a good work ethic, has whole-heartedly committed himself to agriculture.

Thanks to his hard work, he has today become a man known for his determination and serves as an example and reference for other farmers. He has been growing potatoes and wheat for the past 10 years. He is now seeking a loan of 600 USD to buy seeds, fertilizer, fuel and lubricants for his crops in the hopes of being well-prepared for the upcoming season and to produce a good harvest at the end of the season. He can then better meet the needs of his family and improve his work conditions.

loans.use: Purchasing seeds, fertilizer, fuel and lubricants

loans.name: Munira

texts.en:
Munira M. is a native citizen of Istaravshan town. For more than three years, she has been engaged in the business of design for traditional tablecloths and shawls. Munira has four sons and two of them are helping her with the business. She has an unfinished house and two of her sons are adults already and soon she’ll need to marry them off. So Munira wants to expand her business and with the profit she wants to finish building her house. She is asking for a loan of 700 USD that will be spent for purchasing necessary materials for her business. Let’s help this mother to keep working for the well-being of her sons and household!

loans.use: Purchasing of necessary materials

loans.name: Marita

texts.en:
Marita A. is 38-years-old. She has a store in her hometown where she sells a variety of goods. The money she makes from selling her products pays for her family's daily expenses and her childrens' school fees. She wants to expand her business. She dreams of having a chain of stores in her hometown one day.

Marita is asking for a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise for her store. She believes that the loan will help increase her store's profits.

CEVI gives Marita the credit assistance that she needs. CEVI also provides her with training and insurance services.

loans.use: Buy additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Nozimjon

texts.en:
Nozimjon K. is married and has three children whom he is very proud of since they are struggling to get ahead. With the faith that his children would go to college to get ahead, he started a business of processing and selling dried apricots to be able to make enough money to pay for their schooling. This is why he started this business 9 years ago. He is experienced in this kind of business and that allows him to expand his clientele day by day. Right now Nozimjon is requesting 550 USD for purchasing dried apricots to process and sell. With your help, Nozimjon will be able to feel proud that through much effort, his children went to college and are honorable people.

loans.use: To buy dried apricots to expand his business

loans.name: Juraboy

texts.en:
Juraboy O. is a 62-year-old married man who owns a small farm. He is a hard-working man who has fought to provide for his family and educate his children, who today are working adults thanks to his example. Juraboy has been running a business raising and selling cattle. He has 6 years of experience in this field.

Since cattle raising and selling is a profitable business, Juraboy has become a very successful businessman in a very short period. He works hard and spends all his time with his animals, cleaning them, feeding and pasturing them. Now Juraboy wants to expand his business and buy more cattle. With that in mind, he applied for a loan of 550 USD. Juraboy thanks all lenders for their support.

loans.use: Purchasing cattle in order to expand his business

loans.name: Haika

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings) from Tanzania! This is 27-year-old Haika C. from Mbeya. She is married with 3 children, between the ages of 3 and 9. Haika has been running a business selling phone accessories since 2005.

Despite being a ‘developing’ country (forgive the label, there remains no consensus on an acceptable definition), it is amazing how many people have mobile phones in Tanzania and in Africa in general. Not just professionals, but grandmas in villages, school kids, street sellers. It can probably be attributed to a number of factors, led by the fact that it is the only form of phone communication available to most people because there are few landlines, and followed closely by how relatively cheap mobile phones are here.

She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 7 days per week. Haika currently earns about $60 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $475 USD in order to increase stock of phone accessories. In the future, she plans to increase phone accessories and varieties of phones in her business. Haika thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To increase stock of phone accessories and business range

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda A. sells a variety of goods in her neighborhood, which helps her sustain her family. She uses the profit that she gets from selling her products to pay for their daily expenses. She is also able to meet some of her children's needs. She is happy about her business now because it helps her to raise her children well.

Soon, she would like to have a “talaba” farm. Talaba is a kind of seashell that has became popular in the Philippines. That is why she is asking for an additional loan from CEVI. She will use the loan to improve her store and purchase additional merchandise in the hopes of generating more income for the family. When her income has increased enough she would like to have a “talaba" farm of her own.

CEVI helps Erlinda grow her business. CEVI has provided Erlinda with credit assistance, training, and insurance services.

loans.use: Purchase more merchandise for her store

loans.name: Anzhella

texts.en:
Anzhella is married with one child. She runs a small business that offers celebration services (birthdays, parties, etc.) for children. She has been in this business for 2 years. There is very little competition in this business in the city and high demand, so Anzhella has many clients. 

Anzhella would like to get a loan of 7500 UAH to purchase new costumes and equipment. This would allow her to implement new creative ideas and give her clients much happiness. Anzhella's business goal is to have more clients and make this business a stable source of income for her family.

loans.use: Purchase new costumes

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty A. is currently in the business of selling bread, and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Betty is 23 years old and is married with a husband who is an agronomist. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda A. is a pig farmer. She finds it challenging and profitable. She is 56 years old and has 5 children. Her husband, Rogelio, is a jeepney driver. Luzviminda believes that her husband's limited income will make it hard for them to raise and send all of their children to school.

Luzviminda is asking for a loan of Php 6,000 to purchase more piglets and feed for her pigs. She is also interested in looking at other potential sources of income. This will provide her with enough money to care for and educate her children.

CEVI is helping Luzviminda to grow her business. CEVI has provided Luzviminda with credit assistance, training, and insurance services.

loans.use: Buy more piglets

loans.name: Butusyo A.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings) from Tanzania! This is 40-year-old Butusyo K. from Mbeya. She is married with 3 children, between the ages of 14 and 25. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting 2 dependants because their parents passed away with HIV.

Butusyo has been running a rice selling business since 2001. Her business is to buy rice in bulk and sell in retail. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Butusyo currently earns about $300 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $700 USD in order to purchase more rice in bulk. In the future, she plans to open another business and to increase the stock of rice. Butusyo thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more rice in bulk

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita S. is a 51-year-old mother of 4 children and has a dress shop. She cuts and sews fabrics to make clothes for her customers in her home. Perlita started this business in 1980. It has sustained her and her family all this time. She originally invested Php 6,000 in her dress making business because she loved to sew. From her profits, she has been able to send her children to school and buy all her personal needs.

She is asking for a loan of Php 6,000 to buy additional tailoring materials. She will also use the loan to start another business. She is working very hard to achieve a good quality of life for her family. She especially dreams of sending her children to school one day.

CEVI is a field partner of KIVA in the Philippines. CEVI helps more people sustain their businesses by providing credit assistance, training, and insurance services.

loans.use: Buy more sewing supplies

loans.name: Dayandur

texts.en:
Dayandur G. is a hard-working man who strives every day to provide for his entire family, which consists of his wife and four children. He manages a grocery store where he has been selling many staples, such as flour, juice, sweets, and other preserved foods for more than 20 years.

Dayandur has attracted a strong base of customers who are impressed by his efforts to travel to neighboring cities to purchase especially valuable items. In order to purchase additional foodstuffs and increase his inventory, Dayandur is requesting a loan of $1200 USD.

loans.use: To purchase more food products

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian is married with six children and lives in Ntabesi, a quarter in Bamenda, Cameroon.  Vivian plans to invest her loan in her already existing provision. She will divide her loan between articles such as rice, savon, sugar, magi, palm oil and transportation costs.  She plans to contribute 50,000 CFA (approximately $100 USD) of her own savings towards her business plans.  
 
This is Vivian’s second loan from GHAPE; she has been a member since 2007.  From her past experience, her articles are in high demand in her area and she can sell it quite quickly with fast turnover.  Bringing palm oil and other articles from the main market to her community will reduce the transportation costs of her clients as they will be able to purchase these items nearby.  She is confident that this loan will allow her to provide more products and therefore sell more as she will buy in bulk.  
 
With the profits from this loan, Vivian hopes to expand her business.  She also plans to support her children, improve their education, and improve her family’s living standards.  She knows she will not have a problem with her repayments because her loan schedule is set up so that her payments are small and regular.  
 
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase rice, savon, sugar, magi, oil.

loans.name: Alikerem

texts.en:
Alikerem A. is a very loving father devoted to the needs of his three children, whom he adores. Alikerem is a hard-working man who has fought to provide for his family and educate his children. Today his children are studying at school and the university, thanks to his efforts to provide them better educaton.

Alikerem works raising livestock. Every morning he leaves home to take his animals to pasture in the surrounding area. His desire is to improve the quality of his animals. In order to do this he will need to purchase livestock of better breeds. These animals are very costly. He needs capital of $1200 to purchase two calves. Currently he does not have that much money, and therefore he is requesting this loan. Alikerem hopes that you trust in his hard work and honesty.

loans.use: to purchase two calves

loans.name: Vicki A.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings) from Tanzania! This is 25-year-old Vicki M. from Mbeya. She is single with 2 children, at the ages of 3 and 4. Vicki has been running a local restaurant known as ‘Mamalishe’ since 2002.

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all-local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

She works at the business for 5-8 hours per day, 7 days per week, and is assisted by her mother. Vicki currently earns about $80 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $250 USD in order to purchase more rice, cooking oil, salt and beans in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and the range of goods for the business. Vicki thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more rice, cooking oil, salt and beans in bulk

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 24-year-old Flora M. from Mwanza. She is married. Flora has been running a tailoring business since 2003. Her business is purchasing vitambaa (material), vitenge (a traditional Tanzanian cloth with wax print), and kanga (printed cotton fabric often with a border along all four sides) and making them into clothing, mainly for women. She works at the business 12 hours per day, 6 days per week.

Flora currently earns about 250 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to buy materials for making clothes. In the future, she plans to purchase another sewing machine. Flora thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy materials for making clothes

loans.name: Rafael

texts.en:
Rafael A. is 50 years old. He is married and has four children. Rafael is a hard-working man who has fought to provide for his family and educate his children. Today his children are working adults, thanks to his example. Only his youngest child is still under his care. 

Rafael has great experience in cattle breeding; he has worked with cattle since 1997. Over time, he has increased his sales. Now he needs increase number of his calves to increase his profit. The business has been going well and he would like it to continue to grow. Rafael applied for a loan of $1200 to buy two young cattle and fodder. He and his family thank you very much for the support that you offer them in continuing this business and helping them give their children a better quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase two calves and fodder

loans.name: Chamreun's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chamreun N. is a leader of a group of five who all live in the Batheay village in Kampong Cham province. She is a 53-year-old housewife and the mother of a child who is attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. Soun Sary, is a worker. Mrs. Chamreun N. is requesting a loan to buy chickens and chicken feed to start a breeding business. She hopes to increase the family's income and improve their living status.

One member in this group holds an end-of-term loan and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy chickens and chicken feed to start a breeding business.

loans.name: Akhila

texts.en: Akhila A. is 41 years old. She is still working diligently to help her husband, who works as a farmer. Ever since she has lived with her husband, she has worked in the business of buying and selling cattle. She uses the profit to cover the family expenses and her children’s educational fees. Akhila has 4 children. Her first child has already graduated form the university. The other ones are studying in school. The loan of $1200 that Akhila  applied for will be used to purchase 2 calves for expanding her business. She hopes that the business goes well and her family will have a better quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase two calves

loans.name: Anna A.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 39-year-old Anna Ng’ondya from Mbeya. She is married with four children between the ages of 10 and 20.  Anna has been running a genge business since 2008. 

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chili, oil, rice and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

She works at the business for 13 to 16 hours per day, six days per week.  Anna currently earns about US$44 a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of US$600 in order to purchase more beans, rice and cooking oil in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the stock of goods. Anna thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more beans, rice and cooking oil in bulk

loans.name: Tith

texts.en: Mr. Tith K. lives in the Thlos village in Takeo province. He is 59 years old and the father of two children, one of whom is employed in electric factory while the other is enrolled in the local school. He is a construction worker who has a little salary. His wife, Mrs. Oun Kouch, is a farmer who owns 2-hectar field of land to cultivate rice. Mr. Tith K. needs a loan to buy a cow for breeding to earn more income.  His wife is pictured with him.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding to earn more income.

loans.name: Safina

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 22-year-old Safina from Mwanza. She is single. Safina has been running a fish-selling business since last year. She buys fresh fish daily from local fishermen as they come in with their morning catch, and then sells these fish either in the fish market or along the roads of the city. She works at the business for 8 hours per day. Safina currently earns about 325 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to buy more fish to sell. In the future, she plans to add another business. Safina thanks you for your support!

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Qaliba

texts.en:
Qaliba K. is 33 years old, married and has three children. For 8 years Qaliba has dedicated herself to raising and selling cattle, a job that brings economic stability to her family. It is for her family that she works and struggles day in and day out. Her son helps her with the business.
 
She’s asking for a loan of $1200 to invest in her business and buy two more cattle. A successful business will allow her to save enough money so she can provide better life to her children. Qaliba is committed to responsibly repaying the loan within 15 months. With your help, Qaliba can accomplish her dream very soon.

loans.use: to purchase two calves

loans.name: Daria

texts.en:
“Before, I worked in the government, but now I run a small store, so I don’t make as much money. My salary is not enough to support the needs of my children very well. I have to work hard for their future and their needs,” says Daria A.. Daria is a 56-year-old mother of 6 children. Her husband, Primo A., is very supportive of her business. She started her business with very limited capital, only Php 17,000, but it is now well established and growing. Her store is located next to her house and offers a variety of goods to her customers in the neighborhood.

She is asking CEVI for a loan of Php 6,000. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise, which she believes will help her business turn a bigger profit.

CEVI helps Daria grow her business. Joining the CEVI credit program has provided Daria with credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage.

_

loans.use: Buy additional merchandise for her store

loans.name: Saweda

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 24-year-old Saweda S. R. from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. She is married with three children, between the ages of five and eight. Saweda has been running a beauty salon business since 2006. This is the place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, blue hair, and then have it attached to your head, woven, cut, or braided, and made to look like your own.

Saweda works at the business for 9 to 12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Saweda currently earns about 100 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase hair products and cosmetics. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Saweda thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To purchase hair products and cosmetics

loans.name: Azizulla

texts.en:
Azizulla S. isa  60-year-old former teacher on a pension. He is married with five children. Azizulla is the sole breadwinner for his family and his only income comes from the cultivation and sale of large livestock. He sells his livestock at the local market. Every year, he buys young heifers from the farms in adjacent villages. He raises them with the help of his wife and children and then sells the adult cows and bulls to local butchers.

Today, Azizulla is thinking about expanding his business, since the income from his present herd isn't enough to provide for his family. He plans to purchase an additional two young cows. To do this, he needs to invest an additional $1200 in his business.

loans.use: to purchase two calves

loans.name: Emakulata

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Emakulata M. from Mwanza. She is married with two children, ages 14 and 17 years old. Emakulata has been running a shop since 2008. She owns a small "duka" or neighborhood shop in the city where she sells common household and grocery items. She works at the business for 9 hours per day, 6 days per week. Emakulata currently earns about $150 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 USD to purchase more items like rice, cooking oil, wheat flour and biscuits. In the future, she plans to open another business. Emakulata thanks you for your support!

One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries

loans.name: Noeun

texts.en: Mrs. Noeun N. lives in the Angk Prasat village in the Takeo province. She is a 46-year-old widow with seven children, three of whom are employed in garment factory while the others are attending the local school. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. In this plantation, she gets a little income to support her family. Mrs. Noeun N. decided to ask for a loan to buy more rice to re-sell, thus to expand her business and earn more profits.

loans.use: To buy rice to expand her rice to re-sell to earn more profits.

loans.name: Sujayet

texts.en: Sujayet S. and her husband believe that education is the most important inheritance they can give their children. They are both very responsible parents, and they work very hard in agriculture and farming so that they can give their five children the opportunity to finish school. That is an opportunity they never had, due to poor finances. This happy mother has been working in agriculture since getting married and, with the unconditional help of her husband, she buys and sells cattle in order to cover the family’s most urgent needs. Even so, she now finds herself with more bills than she can afford. Therefore, she would like a loan of $1200 in order to buy 10 sheep and fodder, in order to increase their capital. Sujayet and her family are waiting for your quick response.

loans.use: to purchase 10 sheep and fodder

loans.name: Hum

texts.en:
Mrs. Hum S. was born in 1958, and she lives in Trapaing Thmor village in Kampong Cham province. Her husband, Mr. Nhoem Ngim, is a laborer in the field. Even though they try to work hard, they still don't earn enough of an income to provide a better life for their family.

To improve their standard of living, Mrs. Hum S. decided to request for a loan to buy eight piglets, pig food, and build a piggery to start breeding pigs. She has a child who is a tailor. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy eight piglets, pig food, and build a piggery to start breeding pigs.

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
Salimata S. a 34 ans mariée et vit avec son époux et ses quatre (4) enfants (2 garçons et 2 filles) à Banconi, un des  quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Salimata S. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, elle  opta pour le commerce de  céréales (maïs, mil, sorgho) il y a maintenant sept (07) ans. Elle dispose son magasin à Kaboïla I en face de la B.O.A. (Banque Ouest Africaine).
 Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a maintenant cinq (5) ans. Après 5 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association Kotognogontala de Banconi), elle est actuellement à son 4ème prêt individuel et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 23 sacs de Maïs, 10 sacs de Sorgho et 11 sacs de Mil.
Elle s’approvisionne dans les localités environnantes de la ville de Sikasso avant de les revendre soit en gros à une clientèle composée généralement de revendeurs, soit en détail au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle essentiellement composée de chefs de famille.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour  payer les intérêts de son prêt, contribuer aux dépenses de la famille  et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Salimata S., 34, is married and lives with her husband and her four children (two boys and 2 girls) in Banconi, and outlying neighborhood of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Salimata S., after having tried various businesses without success, decided to sell cereals (maize, millet, sorghum) 7 years ago. She has a little store in Kaboïla I opposite the Bank of West Africa (B.O.A.)

With the intention of better satisfying the needs of her ever-growing clientele, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso 5 years ago. After 5 solidarity loans (group loans) in an association with women from her neighborhood (Association Kotognogontala of Banconi), she is now on her 4th individual loan and all the preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed. With this loan she intends to buy 23 sacks of maize, 10 sacks of sorghum, and 11 sacks of millet. She does her buying in places near the town of Sikasso before selling either in bulk to a clientele composed in general of retailers, or retail, for cash or credit, to a clientele essentially composed of heads of families.

She expects to make, thanks to this loan, a monthly profit of 200,000 F CFA which will be used essentially to pay the interest on her loan and help support her family, investing any remainder back into her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing cereals for re-sale

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Mambo ("Hello") from Tanzania! This is 45-year-old Lucia M. from Mwanza. She is married and has 2 children ages 15 and 19 years old. Lucia has been running a grain business since 1995. She sells grain, such as beans and maize, to different customers. She works in her business for 12 hours per day, 7 days per week. Lucia currently earns about $200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 USD to purchase more grains like beans, rice, and maize flour. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Lucia thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more grains like beans, rice, and maize flour

loans.name: Bakhtiyar

texts.en: Bakhtiyar I. is 53 years old. He is married and has three sons. At a young age Bakhtiyar learned to operate a small business from his parents. Through a lot of sacrifice, he became a main producer of agriculture for the area in which he lives. He continued working in the same business after he was married. With the income from the business, he was able to open a dispensary in his house and also raise cattle successfully. He hopes to continue growing and improving his business and offer a better future for his children. Bakhtiyar would like to see them develop into professional, ethical, and hardworking adults. He is requesting a loan of $1200. He will use the loan to buy livestock, as raising and selling animals generates an excellent profit.

loans.use: to purchase two calves

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia D. T. wants to own a store. Today, she sells a variety of goods in the streets because she doesn't have a stall for her merchandise. She is 52 years old and has 9 children. Her husband, Ronieco D. T., is very supportive of her business. She previously worked as a fish dealer but did not like the work. She started a small business instead. “I started my business in 2000 with a limited investment of Php 5,000,” she said. “With hard work, I am able to sustain my business and support the needs of my family,” she added.

She is asking for a loan of Php 16, 000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise for her store. She believes the loan will greatly help her earn bigger profits.

CEVI is helping Virginia achieve her dreams. CEVI gives their clients credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage to help them grow their business.

loans.use: Buy more products to sell in her store

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
Salimata T.   a 44 ans et vit dans une grande famille avec son époux et ses six (6) enfants (2 garçons et 4 filles) à Lafiabougou-Koko, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, Salimata T. entreprend l'activité d’achat et vente de  kola qu'elle a apprise avec ses parents depuis l'âge de 6 ans. Elle mène son activité au grand marché de Médine Sikasso. La Kola(fruit d’un arbre des régions forestières) est un produit associé à tous les évenements sociaux en Afrique (sacrifice, cadeau pour signe de respect  et de considération etc)
 Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ six (6) ans. Après plusieurs prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son 4ème prêt individuel et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt,  8 paniers de kola. Elle s’approvisionne auprès des grossistes de Sikasso avant de les revendre en détail à une clientèle composée généralement des vieilles personnes, des gens organisant les mariages et baptèmes.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 80 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Salimata T., age 44, lives in a large family with her husband and six children (two boys and four girls) in Lafiabougou-Koko, one of the densely populated districts of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having done many kinds of work unsuccessfully, she got started in this work buying and selling kola, which she had learnt with her parents at the age of 6. She operates her business at the grand marketplace Médine Sikasso. Kola (a fruit from a tree in forested areas) is a product associated with all social events in Africa (sacrifices, gifts as a sign of respect and consideration, etc.) Concerned about doing better in satisfying her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso six years ago. After several solidarity loans (group loans) in a women's association in her area, she is on her fourth individual loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. She plans to use this loan to buy eight baskets of kola. These goods are gotten from wholesalers of Sikasso and then sold retail to customers composed generally of the elderly and people organizing marriages and baptisms. She envisions realizing a monthly profit of 80,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to increase her working capital, to help cover family expenses, and to pay the loan interest.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy some Kola

loans.name: Suleyman

texts.en: Suleyman A. is 40 years old and is married with four children. He is a small entrepreneur who sells different kinds of foodstuffs like cookies, candies, soft drinks, juices, tea, sugar, eggs and many others in his grocery store that he has been renting for the last five years. Currently, Suleyman has about $2000 of goods in inventory. His monthly net profit is about $200. Today, Suleyman is requesting a loan of $1200 for the term of 15 months to increase his stock. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once in awhile to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. One of his dreams is that his children progress in their studies. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.

loans.use: purchase more foodstuffs to resell in his grocery store

loans.name: Hilda

texts.en:
Hilda C. is a 35-year-old mother and seaweed farmer. She cultures “Gusu” a type of seaweed that is very popular in the province. Factories that make slippers, plastics, medicines, and other cosmetic products use this type of seaweed. Hilda's husband, Ricardo C., is also a seaweed farmer. Seaweed is the main source of their livelihood. They plant and harvest the seaweed and earn enough for their daily living expenses. Together, they work hard for the future of their children.

Hilda is asking for a loan of Php 18,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase more seaweed for their farm, which she believes will produce a bigger harvest and generate more income for the family.

CEVI helps Hilda grow her business. By providing credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage, CEVI helps more and more clients sustain their business.

loans.use: Purchase seaweed seedlings for farming

loans.name: Mrs. Na Yul Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eleven people living in Phnom Touch village in Kampong Cham province comprise this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for various purposes. Mrs. Na Y., the 34-year-old village bank president, is a rice middleman who buys rice to keep in stock and re-sell later at a better price. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more rice to re-sell to earn more profit. She is a widow with two children who are enrolled in the local school. 

Ten members in this group have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy rice to keep in stock and re-sell later at a better price.

loans.name: Vugar

texts.en:
Vugar A. rents a little store where he sells foodstuffs. He buys his goods in another city. He goes for goods every week. His family consists of a wife and two children who help him at the store. His products are popular in his town for being cheap and fresh. That’s why he has many regular clients. This store is the main financial source in his family, and additional income comes from Vugar`s car, which he uses as a taxi to take local people to other villages.

He wants to take a loan of $1200 for purchasing more goods and to have more profits. And with bigger profits he plans to pay for his children's education.

loans.use: to purchase more food items to sell at his store

loans.name: Noelito

texts.en:
Noelito A., a 33-year-old father of 4 children, buys and resellls scrap and shells for a living. He earns little money buying and selling shells. He uses his earnings to feed his children and send all of them to school. He previously worked as a guard, but admitted that is indeed a very risky job because, according to Noelito, you are protecting properties from thieves. His wife, Anabelle A., helps him raise their kids.

He is asking CEVI for a loan of Php 5,000. He will use the loan to buy more scrap and shells for resale. He thinks this will generate more income, which will make it much easier to provide for the needs of his children. Noelito is also interested in finding another line of business to augment their limited income.

CEVI provides their clients with credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage. Because of CEVI services, more and more entrepreneurs like Noelito are able to make their businesses grow.

loans.use: Buy more scrap materials for sale

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Mambo (Hello!) from Tanzania! This is 39-year-old Victoria M. from Mwanza She is married and has three children between the ages of 13 and 21 years old. She is also responsible for supporting one dependent who is an orphan. Victoria has been running a shop since 2007. She works at the business for 9 hours per day, 6 days per week. Victoria currently earns about $300 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 USD to buy rice, sugar, cooking oil, soaps and beans. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Victoria thanks you for your support!

One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, cooking oil, soaps and beans

loans.name: Gulzadeh

texts.en:
Gulzadeh M. is 46 years old. She is married and has two daughters. She is a very active woman. Six years ago she started her business of raising cattle. She now has 3 cows. She sells the animals after fattening them. She sells the animals to the local market and to local restaurants. With the income she generates she provides a better quality of life for her children. Her children are her main responsibility.

Despite recent success, since her business is still quite small, it doesn't generate enough income for the whole family. Gulzadeh would like to request a loan so she can expand her business and thereby increase her family's income. She will use the profit generated from the business to repay the loan on time. She is asking for a loan of $1200 for the term of 15 months. She will use the loan to buy two more young cattle, which she will sell when they are fully grown. The well-being of Gulzadeh’s family and her business are in your hands.

loans.use: to purchase two calves

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora M., a 30 year-old-mother of four children attending school, is married to a teacher. Currently in the business of selling beer, she is requesting a loan to expand the enterprise.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, all delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Anna E.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 47-yea-old Anna M. from Mbeya. She is widowed with 3 children between the ages of 13 and 24. Anna has been running a local restaurant known as “mamalishe” since 1989. 

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough made from maize flour), plantain (a savory cooked banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

She works at her business for 9 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Anna currently earns about $120 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $375 USD to purchase foods like rice beans, potatoes,cooking oil and other items for her business. In the future, she plans to increase number and varieties of services in her restaurant . Anna thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase food and other items for her business

loans.name: Bahati

texts.en:
Mambo (Hello!) from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Bahati H. from Mwanza. She is single with one 5-year-old child. Bahati has been running a clothing business since 2008. She works at the business for 16 hours per day, 6 days per week. Bahati currently earns about $150 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 USD to purchase "vitenge" (African traditional clothing), bed sheets, and trousers. In the future, she plans to open another business. Bahati thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. loans.use: To purchase vitenge (African traditional clothing), bed sheets and trousers.

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice P., currently in the business of selling bread, is requesting a loan to expand the business. Twenty years old and married to a businessman, she has two children, both attending school.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, all delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand  the business,

loans.name: Azdar

texts.en: Azdar K. is 45-year-old tailor who lives with his wife and three children in the small village of Imishli city. He started his business in 2003 and since that time he gained a number of clientele who trust his experience. Azdar sews different clothes such as shirts, trousers, but the highest demand is for coats. Azdar`s business is the only financial source in his family, and he tries his best to accomplish his main goal, to provide an excellent education for his children who are in school now. Azdar starts his day at 7 in the morning and works till 9 p.m. Now Azdar thinks it is time to improve his working conditions, and for this purpose he applied for $1200 to purchase a modern sewing machine. Azdar and his family count on you for your help.

loans.use: to purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Asunta

texts.en:
Asunta I., 23 and married to a businessman, has three children, all attending school. Currently a seller of maize and millet flour, Asunta is requesting a loan to expand the business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, all delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Mambo (Hello!) from Tanzania! This is 39 year old Rukia G. from Mwanza. She is widowed with three children between the ages of 14 and 17 years old. Rukia has been running a business raising kuku. 

"Kuku" means chicken in Swahili, and raising them for sale is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially among SELFINA clients, for a number of reasons.They require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two, and either add to them as you go, or wait for them to multiply naturally. Secondly, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Thirdly, while they are growing, they produce eggs that can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. 

Rukia has had her business since 1999 and it is doing well. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Rukia currently earns about $150 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 USD to purchase more chicken for the business. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Rukia thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more chickens

loans.name: Akif

texts.en: Akif Q. is a 41-year-old man who sells men's shoes in the central Imishli bazaar. He started his business in 1999, and since that time he has gained respect as a very polite and friendly man. Akif is married and has 2 sons. He starts his working day early in the morning, and after lunch he goes to his second job, where Akif works as a school teacher. Akif would like to purchase new shoes for the spring season, and for this purpose he applied for $1200. This loan he will repay in next 15 months. Let's do our best to help this hard-working man.

loans.use: to purchase seasonal shoes to resell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace T. is currently in the business of selling cold drinks like sodas and icecream and is requesting a loan to expand the business.  Grace is 36 years old and is married with a husband who is a business man. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children.

loans.name: Srey Aun

texts.en: Mrs. Srey Aun O. is a farmer in Thlos village in Takeo province. She owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Yoeun Hun, is a laborer who makes a small income to support the family. Mrs. Srey Aun O. is applying for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase the family income. She is 27 years old and the mother of a child who is ten months old. Her husband is presented with her in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding, to increase the household income.

loans.name: Lemar

texts.en:
Lemar K. he is an educated man with many years of experience. He has been working in the plant propagation business for many years. He has good consistent customers. Lemar's business was quite small when he received his first loan. With the money, he increased his stock, then he improved his business and had even more success.

Lemar has requested a second-cycle loan, 50000 (AFN), with a term of 27 months to enlarge his business and involve one of his sons. Therefore, he wants to work hard to make a better future for all of his family. He is sure that he can further enhance his business with more success and he is very happy about this process of getting a loan in Afghanistan for poor people having financially problems. Lemar thanks all lenders, KIVA and AFSG, in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To increase his stock

loans.name: Anjelina

Anjelina is 40 years old and is married with a husband who is a business man. She has 5 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Khat's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers consists of four people. Its leader, Mr. K., 39, earns a living by catching fish in and around Beung Tunle Sap Lake, an important place for fishing. He normally earns an average of US$ 3 a day from his fishing and has been doing this since 2000. He is married to Kun, 33, who works with him catching fish, and she also is a good mother to five children and cooks delicious foods.

K. is facing problems because his fishing implements break frequently, so he can't catch as many fish as before; thus, he needs a loan in order to purchase more fishing implements.

The other three borrowers are:

S., 55, a local fisherman who is requesting a loan to buy nets for his fishing business;

C., 36, who catches fish for sale, and is asking for a loan to purchase extra nets for fishing; and

C., 28, a grocery seller who is applying for a loan to buy grocery inventory.

The borrowers live in Chong Khneas Commune in Siem Reap Province.

loans.use: To purchase more fishing implements

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Mambo ("Hello!") from Tanzania! This is 33-year-old Joyce N. from Mwanza. She is single with one 5-year-old child. Joyce has been running a women's clothing business since 2007. She works at the business for 8 hours per day, 6 days per week. Joyce currently earns about $100 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $250 USD to buy children's clothing as well as women's clothing. In the future, she plans to add more clothes. Joyce thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Samon

texts.en:
Mrs. Samon P. is a villager in Andoung Pour village in Kampong Cham province. She is a pig breeder. Since her pig business is doing well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy four more piglets and pig food for breeding.

Her husband, Mr. Hen Sopheap, is a construction worker. Mrs. Samon P. is 34 years old and the mother of five children, one of whom is a construction worker while another is employed in a garment factory. Two of the children are attending the local school, and the other is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy four more piglets and pig food for breeding.

Upendo currently earns about $50 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $375 to increase her capital by purchasing more crops in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the stock and the range of her business. Upendo  thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Vorng

texts.en:
Mr. Vorng L. is a villager in Trapaing Por village in Kampong Cham province. He is a village chief. His wife, Mrs. Sorn Thai, is a grocer who owns a small grocery store. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it.

Thus, Mr. Vorng L. is asking for a loan to buy more groceries to earn more profit. He is 52 years old and the father of four children, one is a construction worker, another is a laborer, one stays at home to do housework, and the remaining is attending the local school. His wife is presented on the left the photo.

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Mambo ("Hello!") from Tanzania! This is 40-year-old Jessie M. from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. She is single and has no children. However, she is responsible for supporting one dependent, because his parents cannot care for him. Jessie has been running a hair salon since 2008. Her salon is a place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair or blue hair, and then have it attached to your head, woven, cut, or braided, and made to look like your own. She works at her business for 5-8 hours per day, seven days per week, and is assisted by two employees. Jessie currently earns about $100 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan to purchase ingredients for making food. In the future, she plans to open another business. Jessie thanks you for her support!

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en:
Anthony M. sells groceries and hardware at Ayaase junction near Cape Coast. Anthony has received senior high education. He is married and has 3 children. His wife is a petty trader.

Anthony has been selling hardware for about 5 years. He is responsible for paying the children's school fees, rent, utility bills and other family expenses. His loan will be used to buy more pick axes, nails and other building materials. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to reinvest for the expansion of his building materials business.

loans.use: to buy more groceries, pick axes, nails and other building materials for re-sale

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
Carolina B. is a fish vendor. She sells fish in her neighborhood to earn a living for her family. She does not mind walking in the street to market her big, fresh catch. Someday, she dreams of having a stall in the public market to more easily sell her fish and to earn a bigger income to better support her family's needs. Her husband is also a fisherman. Together, they work hard to send all their children to school.

Carolina is requesting a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI. Aside from buying a new fishing boat, she will use the loan to buy more fish to sell. This will allow her to earn bigger profits and eliminate her worries about having enough money for their daily expenses.

CEVI is helping Carolina grow her business. She enjoys the credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage that CEVI offers to all their clients.

loans.use: Purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Mahmand

texts.en:
This is Mahmand, son of Hazrat Gull. He is 35-years-old, married and the father of nine children. He lives in Nangarhar province Jalalabad city. He is uneducated but is a good farmer who has his own land in his village where he is growing different kinds of vegetables.

Mahmand has four sons and five daughters. His eldest son is a painter working in Kabul, and his second eldest son is a student in the fifth grade in the public school. He helps his father in his spare time. They live in a large house in the village. Mahmand wishes to buy a motorcar, seeds and other necessities for his land.

He needs 40000(AFN) in an individual loan and therefore he contacted the lenders of AFSG and requested this money for 27 months. He has his own capital (50000AFN) and he wants to include it with this loan to buy a motorcar so he bring vegetables easily to the bazaar. He thanks all lenders, KIVA and AFSG in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy a motorcar, seeds and other necessary things for his land

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen K. is married and has 7 dependents. He has received schooling through junior high. Stephen makes and sells palm oil at Dosi near Cape Coast, which he has done for about 8 years.  Stephen uses his income to pay for the children's school fees, rent, utility bills and other expenses. Stephen will use the loan as additional capital to enable him to increase the purchase of palm fruit for the production of palm oil to meet the increase in demand by his customers. With the new profits from his expanded business, Stephen plans to invest in his farm.

loans.use: additional capital to  increase  production of  palm oil

loans.name: Osther

texts.en:
Mambo ("Hello!") from Tanzania! This is 58-year-old Osther M. from Dar es Salaam. She is widowed with three children between the ages of 23 and 34. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependent, because she is am orphan. Osther has been running a grocery business since 2006. She works at the business for 13-16 hours per day, seven days per week and is assisted by one employee. Osther currently earns about $200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan to purchase rice, soft drinks, wheat and maize flour. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and range of the stock. Osther thanks you for her support!
